characters: FROM BEHIND CLAYTON AND ETHAN, TOWARD MARTIN
THE RANGERS, FAVORING CLAYTON AND ETHAN

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Behind the main title and the credits:

dialogues.speaker: LEVEL
dialogues.text: The hoofprints are deeply etched in the ground, picking t way through scrubby desert growth. An occasional tumblewe drifts with the light breeze across the pattern of prints and lightly-blown soil and sand begin the work of erasing them. The CAMERA FOLLOWING the hoofprints

dialogues.speaker: LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: We see the rider now. BACK TO CAMERA, jogging slowly alon heading down a long valley toward a still-distant ranch h with its outlying barn and corrals.

dialogues.speaker: MOVING
dialogues.text: The CAMERA FRAMES and MOVES with the lone horseman. He is ETHAN EDWARDS, a man as hard as the country he is crossin Ethan is in his forties, with a three-day stubble of bear Dust is caked in the lines of his face and powders his  clothing. He wears a long Confederate overcoat, torn at o pocket, patched and clumsily stitched at the elbows. His trousers are a faded blue with an off-color stripe do the legs where once there had been the yellow stripes of Yankee cavalry. His saddle is Mexican and across it he ca a folded serape in place of the Texas poncho... Rider and horse have come a long way. The CAMERA HOLDS an PANS the rider past and we see another detail; strapped o his saddle roll is a sabre and scabbard with a gray silk  sash wrapped around it... Horse and rider pass, moving cl to the ranch as a little girl and a small dog come tearin around the corner of the house.

dialogues.speaker: LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: She is staring wide-eyed at the distant horseman o.s. Her little dog has seen him too and is barking excitedly. DEBBIE quickly reaches to grab the dog by the scruff of t neck, crouching over him. Debbie is 11 years old with a  piquant, memorable face.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Here we must establish and dramatize what it is about her face that is memorable, so that if we were to see her aga five or six years later, we would know it is she -- perha the eye color or the slant of eyebrow, or a trick of  scratching bridge of nose with crooked forefinger.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: The ranch house is of adobe, solidly built, with a sod an cross-timbered roof, deep windows. A small gallery or por extends across the front. AARON EDWARDS comes through the door, attracted by the dog's barking -- and then he, too, sees the approaching horseman and comes farther out -- cu but not at all apprehensive. Aaron is a lean, weathered a tired man, with a down-swept mustache; a gentler-looking than Ethan and possibly a few years older. As he squints off, studying the rider, his older daughter LUCY, comes out to stand behind him. Lucy is from 16 to 1 a pleasant, feminine girl. She is carrying a mixing bowl  with some sort of batter in it, which she now completely  forgets to whip in her interest in the approaching strang In the next instant MARTHA EDWARDS follows the daughter o the porch. Martha is a still-lovely woman, although the y have etched fine wrinkles about her eyes and mouth, and w has worn and coarsened her hands. Those hands will never idle when Martha is on scene... And now, while she shares the family's interest in the approaching horseman, she  automatically notes that Lucy has forgotten her task -- a she takes the mixing bowl from her and stirs the batter.

dialogues.speaker: LATE AFTERNO
dialogues.text: Along the side of the house comes BEN EDWARDS, 14, with a man-sized armload of chunkwood clutched to his chest. He, too, has spotted the stranger and is all attention. So mu so that he trips, but recovers his footing. He pauses to  dump the wood into a woodbox by the door -- his eyes alwa riveted on the oncoming rider -- and then he moves toward the others, biting a splinter out of a finger. Beyond Ben MARTIN PAULEY emerges from the barn and crosses the open  ground heading toward CAMERA. Martin is somewhat under 20 lithe, perfectly coordinated male animal, with Indian-str hair and a white man's eyes. He is carrying bridle or oth horse-gear. He looks to the family on the porch -- to see they recognize the stranger -- then out again. He continu followed by Ben, toward where Debbie crouches over her dog.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: As he rides downslope toward the house. THE CREDITS END.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Martha's eyes widen as she -- even before Aaron recognizes the distant rider. Her hand goes to her mouth check the name that trembles on her lips... An instant la Aaron, too, identifies the oncoming horseman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Ethan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her, frowning, then slowly steps out onto the hard ground. Martha hands the bowl back to Lucy and follo Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROU
dialogues.text: as Ethan rides in and sits his horse, looking down at the There is a noticeable constraint on all of them. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Aaron...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes shift to Martha and hold. Ethan is, and always h been, in love with his brother's wife and she with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit shakily) Hello, Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan slowly, stiffly swings out of the saddle. Aaron and Martha exchange quick glances... troubled, puzzled. Aaron pastes on an uncertain smile as Ethan comes around his ho toward their side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's California?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How should I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mose Harper said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That old goat still creakin'  around?... Whyn't someone bury him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to his saddle pack, begins unlacing it. Ben and D have inched closer -- half-shy, half-curious. Debbie's dog begins sniffing at his heels. Ethan looks do at them - not unfriendly, just a man not used to children

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, ain't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning at Debbie) Lucy, you ain't much bigger than  when I saw you last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Deborah! (pointing) She's Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan looks in the direction of the pointing finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Lucy steps down from the porch and approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy's going on seventeen now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' she's got a beau! Kisses him,  too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough... Go on inside and  help Lucy set the table... You, too,  Deborah!

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER ANGLE
dialogues.text: as Martin -- with slightly averted face -- crosses to tak the bridle of Ethan's horse and lead him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wheeling on him) MOMENTO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin checks his stride, stares in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contritely) Martin!... Here we've been standing...  Ethan, you haven't forgotten Martin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Mistook you for a half-breed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (levelly) Not quite... Quarter Cherokee. The  rest is Welsh... So they tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done a lot of growin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Ethan found you squallin' in  a sage clump after your folks was  massacred...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bluntly) It just happened to be me... No need  to make any more of it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of your horse for  you, Uncle Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, he starts to lead away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin stops again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He completes unlacing the pack and takes it -- treating i as though it contained something of value. Martin watches with a touch of resentment: Ethan doesn't trust him. Ethan turns and sees the look. He doesn't care what Marti thinks, nor does he explain. Martin leads the horse off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Supper'll be ready by the time you  wash up... Let me take your coat for  you, Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hesitates, then grudgingly surrenders it -- conscious its sorry condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling faintly) And... welcome home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just nods, then turns to follow Aaron around the side the house toward the wash-up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: She stands alone, looking after Ethan -- his coat in her  arms. She holds it against her breast for just a moment a her eyes are tender.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The family is finishing dinner -- and the scene is not qu but almost, a still-life. Loud in the room is the pendulu tick of a Seth-Thomas clock on the mantel above the firep in which logs are burning briskly. Ben crouches near the  fireplace, fascinatedly examining the scabbard and sabre  Ethan has brought home from the wars. He tries to ease the blade just a bit out of its scabbard Aaron sits at one end of the hand-hewn table, Martha at t other. At her right is Ethan, his fork scraping the last  crumb off his plate. Lucy sits at her father's right and  Martin at his left. Next to Martin is Debbie. In the cent of the table is the sorry remnant of what was once a meal Lucy and Martin have finished eating. Aaron is sipping hi coffee, and Martha -- her own plate largely untasted -- i watching Ethan. Ethan has shaved, changed his shirt. He straightens  contentedly and every eye is on him, expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock rattles alarmingly -- the usual preliminary to striking; and then it bangs out the strokes like a fire-a gong. Eight fast clangs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben! Deborah! Bed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I've got to help with the dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not tonight... Ben, put that sword  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a sword, ma... it's a saber! (moving to Ethan) Did you kill many damYankees with  this sabre, Uncle Ethan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (matter-of-factly) Some...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many damYankees, Uncle Ethan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben!... Martin, he'll sleep in the  bunkhouse with you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin nods and crosses to kiss Martha good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Aunt Martha... Uncle  Aaron... (he hesitates) Good night, Uncle Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan doesn't like being called Uncle -- as we must know  from the quick look he shoots at Martin. But he acknowled it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben reluctantly puts the scabbard away, turns to Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you tell me tomorrow about the  war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war ended three years ago, boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It did?... Then whyn't you come home before now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEN!... Go 'long with Martin. MARCH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ben reluctantly heads out with Martin, Deborah crosses Ethan's side and studies him gravely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy's wearing the gold locket you  gave her when she was a little girl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She don't wear it much account of it  makes her neck green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aghast) Deborah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively) Well, it does... But I wouldn't care  if you gave me a gold locket if it  made my neck green or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan looks at her gravely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Fraid I... (then he remembers  something, rises) Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to where his pack is -- a side table or someth and burrows into it. Debbie is at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a gold medal or medallion -- something appropriate Maximilian of Mexico -- suspended by a long multi-colored satin ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! LOOK! My gold locket!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds it high for mother -- and all -- to see. Martha takes it and reacts at its weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's solid gold... Ethan, I don't  think she's old enough...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let her keep it... Just something I  picked up in Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha reluctantly surrenders it to Debbie's eager hand. Aaron hasn't missed the word "Mexico" and looks sharply a Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, Uncle Ethan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Debbie) Come along...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two girls leave the main room. Martha and Aaron both  look at Ethan -- half expecting some further explanation. He turns from them and looks into the fire. Martha begins clear the table. Aaron gets up, takes a pipe and a spill lights it at the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passed the Todd place comin' in... What happened to 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gave up... went back to the  cotton rows... So'd the Jamisons... Without Martha, I don't know... She  wouldn't let a man quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan turns and looks at her -- still busy with her dishe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (change of tone) Ethan, I could see it in you before  the war... (Ethan looks at him) You wanted to clear out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha freezes in what she's doing -- listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you stayed out beyond all need  to... WHY?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan can't answer, but he takes it as a challenge and al welcomes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard) You askin' me to clear out now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straightening --  with grave dignity) You're my brother... You're welcome  to stay as long as you got a mind  to... Ain't that so, Martha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost a whisper) Of course he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expect to pay my own way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha resumes her activity. Ethan crosses to his pack,  reaches into it for a leather pouch, brings it back and t it onto the table. It lands with a resonant clink. Both Martha and Aaron draw close to the table. (NOTE TO WINTON HOCH: This scene should be dramatically b lighted.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's sixty double eagles in  there... twelve-hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens a waistline shirt button and hauls out a leather money belt and drops that on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' twice that in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches into the belt and takes out a few mint-fresh g pieces which he slides across the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...only these got the late Emperor  Maximilian's picture on 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha picks up one of the gold pieces, staring at the fa on the coin: the same as that on the medal -- staring sha then at Ethan. Aaron is examining another coin with a  different interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mint fresh... not a mark on 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances questioningly at Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron shrugs and crosses to a barrel chair. He raises the seat and lifts out a pair of old boots, some rags of clot and then raises a false-bottom lid and drops pouch and mo belt into it. Carefully he replaces everything. During th Ethan's attention has gone to Martha's hand, to one cut  finger, its wound barely healed. He takes the hand -- gen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods and withdraws the hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) You were always hurting about your  hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks quickly at him and self-consciously tries to hi her hands, conscious of their work-worn appearance. Then for a moment their eyes meet and hold -- and a world sadness and hopelessness is in the look. Aaron closes the seat of the barrel chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time for bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up one of the lamps and starts away toward their bedroom door. Martha looks at Ethan again. His expression bitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night, Ethan... Come 'long, Martha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns obediently and follows Aaron. Ethan looks after them and waits as Aaron opens the bedroom door. Martha go into it and Aaron follows and closes the door. Ethan crosses to the lamp on the mantel, blows it out. Only the firelight strikes his face as he stares brooding at the closed bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie's dog is barking excitedly as six horsemen slowly  ride toward the house and dismount. A lamp goes on inside

dialogues.speaker: THE SIX HORSEMEN ARE
dialogues.text: CAPTAIN, THE REVEREND SAM CLAYTON, a big man with frosty  blue eyes, graying hair, a bristly full mustache and the of grave and resolute authority. He is a minister of the  Gospel with a .44 on his hip. LARS JORGENSEN, the Edwards' neighbor, is a harried littl man, Scandinavian. As we shall find out soon, he has a br and buxom wife and a rather astonishing brood of children BRAD JORGENSEN is one of these: sandy-haired, brash, amia impulsive. He is in his early twenties. CHARLIE MacCORRY, slightly older than Brad, is Sergeant o Company A of the Rangers. (He is also Company A.) Charlie a taciturn, gently-spoken, competent man, clearly pattern by his association with Captain, the Rev. Sam. MOSE HARPER is an old scout -- a walking bone-rack, yet  capable of tireless feats of endurance. Some think him  "tetched" yet he has managed to endure to his age during time and in a region where few men lived to see their  grandchildren. He wears a ragged dark overcoat in all wea a narrow-brimmed hat with a feather in its band. ED NESBY is a rancher and homesteader in his mid-thirties resolute, honest, self-effacing; nothing picturesque or  dramatic about him; just a solid citizen and a realist.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: She is at the window of her bedroom, wrapper clutched wit one hand, lamp upraised in the other as she stares into t dawn to see who these callers are. We hear the heavy foot falls of the approaching men, then a loud knock thrice  repeated -- an ominous sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron! Open up!... Sam Clayton!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is opened by Aaron -- holding a lamp and a gun. is only partly dressed -- pants, boots, undershirt. The b of light slashes across the faces of Sam and some of the behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend... Come in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to get you out of bed so  early... (as Martha enters,  tightening her wrapper) Mornin', Sister Edwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Reverend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars Jorgensen claims someone bust  into his corral last night and run  off his best cows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean those pure breds he just  bought?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jorgensen enters -- an angry little man -- closely follow by Mose Harper, who is grinning foolishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time I raise pigs, by golly!   You never hear of anyone running off  pigs, I bet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Injuns has 'em... Caddoes or Kiowas... Kiowas or Caddoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably) Caddoes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mose spots Martha and at once whips off his hat and makes her an exaggerated cavalier's bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Respects to a charmin' lady, ma'am. ...Respects, respects...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Nesby enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee's made if you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee'd be fine, sister...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads for the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an old man's whimper) My bones is cold...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes brighten as he looks toward the fire and spots a rocking chair. He shuffles toward it, plants himself and  begins rocking and half-crooning to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or bumble bees, by golly... I show  them dirty rustlers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crooning) Lookit me, old Mose Harper, rockin'  in a rockin' chair... I'm a-goin' to  set 'n rock, 'n rock, 'n rock, 'n  rock...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door opens to admit Martin, fully dressed and a with Charlie MacCorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over here, Martin... Aaron...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin ranges himself next to Aaron and both face Clayton

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raise your right hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha sets out cups on the table, begins pouring the cof During the swearing-in, Ethan will enter the room from th inner door -- unnoticed by the other men, but not by Mart And as the scene plays, the audience must always be consc of the by-play of glances between Martha and Ethan as the face the prospect of being left in this house together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are hereby volunteer privates in  Company A of the Texas Rangers and  will faithfully discharge the duties  of same without recompense or monetary  compensation -- meaning no pay!...  Amen and get your shirt on, will  you, Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stubbornly) Ain't goin' volunteerin' after  rustlers without my morning coffee,  Reverend... Drink your own!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sternly -- as he  reaches for his cup) From now on, call me 'Captain'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Ethan advances and calmly appropriates the cup Clayto is reaching for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mockingly) Captain the Reverend Samuel Johnson  Clayton!... Mighty impressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton marks his surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dourly) Well... the prodigal brother... When'd you get back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan sips his coffee and doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't seen you since the surrender. (a pause) Come to think of it, I didn't see  you at the surrender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe in surrenderin'... I  still got my sabre, Reverend... never  turned it into any ploughshare  neither!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is no time for kaffee-klatch while a  man's beef is been run off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Injuns, Ethan... (taps his nose) Caddoes or Kiowas... Mose Harper,  drinkin' coffee in a rockin' chair. ...ay-eh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha has left the room briefly to fetch Aaron's shirt a vest and stands behind him. Aaron drains his cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan, countin' on you to look after  things while I'm gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan -- cup to his lips -- looks over its rim at Martha Aaron starts to put on his shirt. Their eyes meet briefly then she looks away. Ethan sloshes the dregs of his cup i the fire -- some of it spattering Mose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't goin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sure is goin'... He's sworn in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Well, swear him out again!... I'll  go with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha stands submissively, with her head bent, eyes aver as Ethan crosses the room to get his coat, guns, etc. Aar follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Ethan, I ain't sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't argue!... And stay close... Maybe they're rustlers... and maybe  this dodderin' old idiot ain't so  far wrong...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thankin' ye, Ethan... thankin' ye. Kind words...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grudgingly) All right... I'll swear you in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can forget that... (as Sam stares) Wouldn't be legal anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? (a pause -- then  shrewdly) You wanted for a crime, Ethan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha waits -- intent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You askin' as a Reverend or a Captain,  Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm askin' as a Ranger of the  sovereign state of Texas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a warrant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fit a lot of descriptions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (levelly) I figger a man's only good for one  oath at a time... I took mine to the  Confederate States of America... (he pauses -- then) So did you, Reverend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks past him then -- at Martha and then at Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stick close, Aaron...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Martha again... and then strides out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ethan emerges he is brought to a momentary halt by sig of a couple -- Brad and Lucy -- in each other's arms, sta near the saddled horses of the posse. Clayton and Jorgens following him out, spot the couple, who now belatedly are conscious of their audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad!... Is no time for lolly- gagging...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In confusion, Lucy runs back around the side of the house Brad -- unrepentant -- grins at his irascible old man and heads for his waiting horse. Clayton chuckles and turns t Martha, who has followed them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like I'll be reading the lines  over that pair before long, sister  Edwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is no time for talking weddings... Better say prayers for those dirty  thieves, by golly... running off a  man's beef...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mose, last to emerge, bows elaborately to Martha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grateful to the hospitality of yore  rockin' chair, ma'am...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are mounting. Mose nimbly vaults onto the back of his horse -- which he rides bareback, with only a blanket pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Ethan and Martin ride to join the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get on with it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAIT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes flying out of the house in her long flannel nig and runs to Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin! Ride me as far as the well!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grab hold!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swings her up in front of his saddle. They start away. Ethan is last to ride out. He is watching Martha. He brin a gloved hand up in a salute. She starts to raise her han but only brings it just above her waist, a fluttering ges with tremulous fingers. It is the last he will ever see o her alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the posse slowly rides out, with Ethan last. Martin re in to let Debbie slip to the ground. Ethan passes her. Debbie stands watching the men ride away, waving at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) DEBORAH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and comes running back -- CAMERA PANNING -- to little group on the porch; Ben in the door; Lucy crossing the porch; Aaron and Martha at the steps.

dialogues.speaker: POSSE
dialogues.text: Ethan and Mose are advancing at a steady walk, both men  leaning slightly out of their saddles to study the terrai the trail they are following. Out to one side -- fifty ya distant -- is the main body of the posse: Sam, Jorgensen, Charlie, Ed, moving roughly parallel to Ethan but at a fa clip. Martin comes riding in toward Ethan from behind CAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Uncle Ethan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan reins in -- compressing his lips at the "Uncle." Mose waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somethin' mighty fishy about this  trail, Uncle Ethan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop callin' me 'uncle'... I ain't  your uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't have to call me 'sir' neither... Nor grampaw neither... Nor Methuselah  neither... I can whup you to a  frazzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mose lets out a snickering laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you want me to call you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name's Ethan... Now what's so mighty  fishy about this trail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, fust off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks and all turn at a distant hail from Jorgensen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! Look!

dialogues.speaker: RISE OF GROUND
dialogues.text: He is holding his rifle with both hands straight over his head -- and he repeats the signal until he sees they have seen him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Brad! He's found them... Come on!

dialogues.speaker: THE DISTANCE
dialogues.text: as Jorgensen digs spurs and leads the way. The other ride follow.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He waits grimly until he sees them coming, then wheels hi mount and takes off over the hill.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSSE
dialogues.text: as it comes up the rise and the men rein in on the crest. Jorgensen stares and his face mirrors shock and dismay. The other men look down into the long valley on the far s with equally grim expressions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call that young fool back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jorgensen doesn't even seem to hear him. Angrily Ethan wh out revolver and fires into the air. Then he swings his a in a come-back gesture. He rides out ahead then a short  distance and dismounts... and slowly the others follow. We see now, the bodies of a few bulls stiffening in the s Ethan goes to the nearest one. A feathered lance is drive into it. He pulls the lance out. Mose comes over beside h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Caddo or Kiowa, huh?... Ain't but  one tribe uses a lance like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the lance to Mose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost a whisper) Ay-he... Comanch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad rides in -- shrill with anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killed every one -- an' not for food  either... Why'd they do a thing like  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stealing the cattle was just to pull  us out... This here's a murder raid... (facing Jorgensen) It shapes up to scald out either  your place... or my brother's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jorgensen wilts and casts an anguished look back over the miles they have ridden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama!... Oh please... please no... BRAD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that one word, Jorgensen calls upon his son to f and they take off... fast. Ed Nesby and Charlie MacCorry  follow. Sam Clayton pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jorgensen's place is closest... If  they're not there, we'll come straight  on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he too rides. Martin swings his horse back to where  Ethan and Mose still are standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy! (he starts toward his  horse) It's forty miles, sonny... Horses  can do with some grain and a little  rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comanch generally hits at moonrise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moonrise!... It'll be midnight  before... I ain't waitin'...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wheels his horse and goes tearing to catch up with the others. Ethan shrugs and stoically takes grain bag to fee his horse. Mose does the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wisht it was Caddoes... or Kiowas... (shakes his head) Comanche...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan just gives him an angry look and then ruthlessly be discarding every bit of unnecessary equipment from his sa

dialogues.speaker: SUNDOWN
dialogues.text: Nothing moves. Nothing could be more tranquil. The shadow are long. A thin wisp of smoke rises from the chimney. An then Debbie's little dog trots around the side of the hou out into the yard.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOG
dialogues.text: He comes to a standstill and his nose is working. He begi to make excited little sounds deep in his belly. Then he lies down, muzzle between his paws, watching,  listening.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Debbie sits on the floor, playing with a little rag doll. The slanting blaze of the setting sun makes a brilliant a of light in which she is sitting. Beyond her, on the porc steps, Ben is squatting, whittling a piece of pine into a slingshot frame. We hear Martha and Lucy busy with the di Aaron comes from behind CAMERA and stands in the doorway, absently rapping out his pipe. Near the doorway, on a woo peg, hangs his gun, belt. He puts the pipe in his pocket glances down at Deborah, intent on her play. He looks swi at where the women are busy - then stealthily eases the g from its holster and slides it under his shirt. He hasn't made a sound and is sure he's got away with it. He clears his throat noisily and reaches for a light shot pegged above the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think I'll see if I can pick off a  sage-hen or two, Martha...

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA AND LUC
dialogues.text: busy at the wooden sink. Martha doesn't turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do that, Aaron...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still pleased with  himself) Won't go far...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps out. Only then does Martha turn -- and her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and FRAMING the empty holster, as Aaron pauses on the por

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, the days are getting shorter!

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA AND LUCY
dialogues.text: as Lucy heads for the lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Lucy!... We don't need the lamp yet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy frowns at her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily) Let's enjoy the dusk a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron is slowly scanning the terrain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ben) Mind you sweep up them shavin's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Pa... (undertone -- man to  man) An' if you see any sage-hens, I'm  ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron stares as the boy shifts a fold of blanket, or what by his side -- to disclose Ethan's cavalry sabre. Aaron s and rubs the youngster's head, then sets out across the y

dialogues.speaker: MOVING
dialogues.text: Debbie's dog rises at Aaron's approach and joins his mast as they set out across the plain.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: He is walking through the scrub and brush grass, every se alive and straining. He pauses every three or four stride casting each quadrant in turn. Once he whips, gun ready, a sage-hen or quail whirrs up not far from him. He smiles grimly as he watches it fly away. He keeps on.

dialogues.speaker: AT PORCH
dialogues.text: Martha comes to stand in the doorway. Ben doesn't look at her. His eyes -- like hers -- are fixed on the figure of man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) It's all right, ma... I been  watchin'...  Only I wish...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) What, Ben?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish Uncle Ethan was here. Don't  you, ma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't answer. Lucy comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, I can't see what I'm doing!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOT YET, LUCY!...

dialogues.speaker: PAST AARON
dialogues.text: He stands on the near slope of a rise and then gradually  moves toward its summit, so that only head will be  silhouetted. He drops to one knee, half-leaning against t slope and slowly looks out... The CAMERA PANS very slowly following his careful sweep of the terrain. The scene is entirely peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: with narrowed eyes slowly scanning the ground. Suddenly t head whips right. We hear a bird's sharp call.

dialogues.speaker: A SMALL BIRD
dialogues.text: It is taking flight, sweeping away in erratic arcs.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: He squints closely at the ground from which the bird had  flown. Then slowly his eyes range toward the left.

dialogues.speaker: PAST AARON
dialogues.text: Across the meadow, a shadow seems to touch the grass and once a covey of quail takes off, whirring loud. Aaron wai no longer, but slides down the slope and starts running a crouch for the house, stopping every so often to look  backward.

dialogues.speaker: SUNSET
dialogues.text: NOTE TO W. HOCH: What J.F. has in mind for this and the  following scenes is the same kind of dramatic use of red achieved in "Yellow Ribbon" in the scene telling of Custe defeat. They are standing in the ruddy glare of the sunset and Be has Ethan's sabre in his hand. We hear Aaron coming at a  run, breathing hard. Ben takes a step as though to go to  him, but Martha's hand at once is on his shoulder. Aaron  gains the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the house, boy... and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts finger to his lips, sign for Ben to say nothing. Ben nods and goes inside. Aaron and Martha face each othe the question large on her face. Slowly he nods the  confirmation of her fears, then gently propels her ahead him through the door.

dialogues.speaker: SUNSET
dialogues.text: The room is deeply shadowed except where the dull crimson the sun through door and windows slashes the blackness. Ben is waiting and Martha turns toward Aaron as he pulls door shut, bars it and sets the shotgun down. He takes th revolver from his waist and Martha holds it as he reaches for his gun belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, close the shutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buckling on his gun belt, he moves toward the middle of t room, looking around him, taking inventory of his resourc Lucy slowly approaches, biting a knuckle, eyes wide with  fright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One shutter closes and the bar of light they were standin in goes out. Martha, Aaron and Lucy are dark silhouettes against the red beam from another window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sudden fear) Where's Deborah?... (calling it) DEBORAH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie emerges from a shadowed corner into a beam of ligh She is clutching her rag doll, nibbling a cookie. She hol it for them to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only took one, ma... Topsy was  hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben closes the shutter. And now the room is almost comple blacked out, except for the dying light filtering through the rifle ports of the closed shutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This should be an expansive view to convey the fact that posse has split -- the main group heading for the Jorgens place, Martin forking off to race alone for the Edwards r Coming toward and passing CAMERA is Martin, riding all ou Several hundred yards away and moving in a divergent dire are the others -- Brad and Charlie, Sam, Jorgensen and Ed Nesby. The men are not compactly bunched, but strung out, each taking his own best course and his own speed... As t riders pass and the dust of their passing, we see two oth riders -- Ethan and Mose -- minute specks in the distance possibly a mile or two behind.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN AND MOSE
dialogues.text: (NOTE TO W. HOCH: What we are trying to get here is that  moment of swift transition from twilight to night; of rid briefly touched with the last colors of day and then, as  they pass, becoming one with blue shadows of night.) Ethan and Mose are holding their mounts to a jog, in mark contrast to the all-out pace of the others. The CAMERA PA after them as the dark fingers of the night stretch acros the valley. The wind begins to rise and somewhere off in hills a coyote pack yaps.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Aaron is little more than a shadowy silhouette as he peer into the night through a partly-opened shutter. Suddenly room leaps alight as Lucy opens an inner door and enters, holding a lighted lamp. Aaron closes the shutter, spins o her angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha crosses the room swiftly and blows out the lamp. In the brief moment the room has been lighted, we see tha Lucy is carrying a dark shawl in one hand; that Ben is  crouched at another window -- rifle ready; and that Debor is on her feet -- standing like a child who is being dres

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I couldn't find the  shawl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry, Martha... Moon's fixin' to  rise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cautiously swings the shutters open. A pale light filt into the room. We see Martha wrapping the shawl around  Deborah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly to the child) We're going to play the sleep-out  game... Remember?... Where you hide  out with grandma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's she buried?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you'll go along the ditch -- very quietly -- like a... (her voice breaks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a little mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches for the child, but he has to wait for Martha's last embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There!... And you won't come back or  make a sound... no matter what you  hear? Promise!... No matter what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise... Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Child, child!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't I have Topsy to keep me company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here she is, baby... Baby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron takes the child, swings her out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down low -- go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha would come to the window to look out, but Aaron ba her with an arm and draws back to the side of the window watch her go... Outside the little dog barks a welcome an presumably starts to follow the girl. Aaron reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoarse whisper) Here dog... here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog whines but obeys. Aaron continues watching the ch course -- unconsciously imitating her every run and twist Then he smiles and we may see the brightness in the corne of his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reached the ditch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the shutters and turns -- and his arms go aroun Martha, weeping soundlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be all right, mother... she'll  be all right.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Nothing stirs and we hear nothing. Then, with faintest li rustle, Debbie comes snaking along the ground into the ho between the two graves and lies there face down, pressed  against Topsy. She becomes one with the earth and the  stillness. And then the moonlight strikes the tips of the scrub growth and as a cloud scuds by, the moonlight revea something glittering -- like beads. And the CAMERA from t ground-level shot

dialogues.speaker: FROM EXTREME LOW ANGLE
dialogues.text: The Comanche we are later to know as SCAR is painted for tall, savage, mockingly looking down at what we know is t child's hiding place... And in that instant, from a dozen quarters and a dozen throats, sounds the wild yammer of t warwhoop!

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He stands beside his spent and fallen horse. Its breathin is a rasping whistle. Martin tries to haul its head up. Useless. Breathing hard himself, his face ashen in the  moonlight, Martin looks desperately off in the direction the ranch. Then he jerks the rifle from its saddle scabba struggling with it because it is under the horse. He free then -- listening... And we hear the steady beat of two  horsemen approaching. Martin knows who they are and his f is alive with hope. He gets the rifle free at last and go running toward the oncoming riders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Ethan!... Ethan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA SWINGS with him and we see Ethan and Mose  approaching at the same steady gait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waving) Uncle Ethan... it's me... Martin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan doesn't slacken, nearly rides him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of my way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin goes sprawling to his hands and knees. Mose contin without slowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately) Mose! Wait!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes running, stumbling after the riders -- desperatel calling to them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan!... Mose!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then at the crest of the rising ground, he stops -- We see in the distance the glow of a fire leading from th barns and the hayricks and the house of Aaron Edwards. Martin runs down the slope.

dialogues.speaker: NI
dialogues.text: (NOTE TO W. HOCH: Here again that use of red is suggested The ANGLE is past the porch uprights toward Mose and Etha as they ride in. Little tongues of fire are licking the e of the uprights. A few arrows, imbedded in the wood, are  burning along their shafts. Beyond are the glowing ashes the hayricks and the charred, smouldering rails of the co There are no bodies in evidence... The red glow of the bu is on the faces of the men as they dismount. Ethan strides to the porch, knocking away one of the blaz arrows as he heads to the door. He stops there -- and wha he sees makes the big shoulders droop, the huge frame slu Slowly then -- and removing his hat -- he goes in. Mose  shuffles to the edge of the porch and squats there and ro back and forth, his face working and crying soundlessly w senile grief. We hear a splintered door crash from its hi within the room and Ethan's muffled voice calling through the house:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy?... Deborah? Lucy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides back through the main room and out onto the po just as Martin comes at a shambling run across the yard. Ethan takes a few steps out toward him. Martin would pass him, but Ethan grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) You stay out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin tries to fight his arm free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing for you to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leggo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan turns him and drives a brutal right to his jaw. Mar goes down -- out cold. And only now do we understand how  merciful the blow was as Ethan looks compassionately at t fallen figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let him go in there, Mose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he takes off at a stumbling run for the hilltop.

dialogues.speaker: ET
dialogues.text: as he nears the graves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Lucy -- Lucy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs in, looking around him. He sees the little dog, d on the ground. And then he sees a shadowed something: The shawl Debbie had worn. It is spread out, almost as th concealing a body. Fearfully he stoops and pulls it away. There is nothing there, but the shawl. He drops to his kn his head bowed, his face tortured. The moonlight is clear the face of the nearer headboard. It is of weathered wood and the chiselled letters on it read:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a good WIFE & MOTHER In her 41st year

dialogues.speaker: SLOWLY PANNING
dialogues.text: The funeral is begun. In the foreground are three newly- made crosses at the head of as many open graves -- which need not see. With head bared, Sam Clayton is concluding prayer. Near him stand the Jorgensen family: Mrs.  Jorgen Lars and LAURIE -- blonde, just beginning to reach her  maturity -- and a stepping-stone of tow-headed children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and to Your keeping we commend  the souls of Aaron... Martha... and  Benjamin Edwards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jorgensen and Laurie -- impelled by the same feminin sympathy and interest -- turn to look at Ethan and Martin The PANNING CAMERA picks them up...Ethan standing dry-eye looking at the grave of Martha; Martin -- with bruised li looking out across the plain. Clayton now opens his small, well-worn Bible to a marked  page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man that is born of woman is of few  days and full of trouble...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan looks at him, angrily, impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cometh forth like a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) Amen!... Put an 'amen' to it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...like a flower and is cut down... Amen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan turns on his heel and walks -- CAMERA PANNING -- to where Ed Nesby has been holding the horses. Brad is alrea mounting. Mose is there too and Charlie MacCorry.  Silhou against the dawn light are the rifles in each man's saddl scabbard. Clayton is right behind Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie--you and Brad ride point! ...Don't get too far ahead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young riders spur out.

dialogues.speaker: JORGENSEN
dialogues.text: Ethan is about to mount when Mrs. Jorgensen comes up and  catches his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan... (he turns impatiently) Those girls mean as much to me as  though they were my own... Maybe you  don't know my Brad's been sittin' up  with Lucy... and my Laurie's real  fond of Martin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan glances back at where Martin and Laurie are standin

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING LAURIE AND MARTIN
dialogues.text: The girl is looking at Martin full of compassion, tries t console him by taking his arm and squeezing it as he star blindly at the graves and Jorgensen stolidly beginning th work of shovelling them full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan looks back at her -- stone-faced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) I'd be obliged if you'd get to the  point, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am... I am... It's just that I  know Martha'd want you to think of  her boys as well as her girls... And  if the girls are... dead... Ethan,  don't let the boys waste their lives  in vengeance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan shrugs his arm free and mounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise me, Ethan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ignores her and turns angrily to where Martin is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) Come on, if you're comin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He digs spurs and rides out with the others. Martin comes over, with Laurie a step behind. His face is set, his eye almost unseeing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a heartbroken murmur) Oh, Martin... Martin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll find them, Mrs. Jorgensen... We'll find them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swings into his saddle. Laurie impulsively runs to his side, steps onto the toe of his stirruped boot and pulls  herself up to his level to kiss him hard and full upon th mouth. He looks at her dully, as though hardly conscious of it. she is back beside her mother. Martin rides away after th others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) I almost hope they don't find them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurie looks at her mother and understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SEARCH THEME begins as we see the riders in turn. A series of portraits of the men. CLOSE SHOT - BRAD AND CHARLIE - riding point, they come t pause, surveying the terrain ahead. Charlie, with an arm  signal, indicates he will take the left. Brad nods and he rides out to the right. THE MAIN BODY OF THE MEN, Clayton passing first, expressi resolute, competent... Then Ed Nesby and old Mose, squint at the ground as they ride, all but sniffing like an old  hound dog.

dialogues.speaker: 63A
dialogues.text: MARTIN - Next to last in file. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: 63B
dialogues.text: ETHAN - His face a study of relentless purpose.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD AND CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The two men are at a cairn of rocks -- their horses nearb In the near distance, Clayton is leading the men of the s party at a fast clip toward the cairn. Charlie is standin Brad tearing the rock cairn apart. In Charlie's hands is Comanche head-dress of polished buffalo horn and feathers Brad doesn't even look up as the men ride in and dismount but continues his grim work of uncovering the buried Indi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another one, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This 'un come a long way 'fore he  died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's seven we can score up  to your brother, Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What don't you like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Injun's on a raid generly hides their  dead so you won't know how many  they've lost... If they don't care  about us knowin', it only spells one  thing... they ain't afraid of us  followin' -- or of us catchin' up  with 'em either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can back out any time, Nesby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't say that... (angrily indicating  Brad) What's he doin' that for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to be sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad shifts another rock and Looks grimly upon the face ( of the dead Comanche. Then he spits at it and stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grim) Let's get along...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Brad) Why don't you finish the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that he strides to the cairn, whipping a knife out. crouches over the body (O.S.) concealing what he is doing he bends to his bloody task. Sam Clayton crosses to stand behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gravely) What good does that do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By what you preach... none!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands now and he faces Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But by what the Comanche believe --  now he can't enter the spirit land,  but has got to wander forever between  the winds... because I took his mangy  scalp!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flings the scalp down and grinds it into the dirt with his heel... He wipes clean the blade of his knife as he  crosses back to his horse. The men mount (those who have  dismounted) and they ride off.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD AND MARTIN
dialogues.text: Brad is looking out into the night -- strain and tension every line. Beyond them we may see some of the other men sitting or sprawled on the ground near a sheltered fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper) If only she's alive... I'll make it  up to her... No matter what's  happened... I'll make her forget...  She's just got to be alive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan crosses behind them carrying his blanket roll. He l at them sourly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get some rest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move off, heading for their blankets. The CAMERA HOL on Ethan as he rolls up his blanket and turns on his side He fishes a miniature out of his pocket and gravely studi it by the light of the flickering little fire.

dialogues.speaker: THE MINIATURE
dialogues.text: It is a picture of Martha. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to show  Ethan studying it gravely, then putting it away and lying back to stare broodingly into the night.

dialogues.speaker: SUNSET
dialogues.text: The four faces are just over the ridge, peering at someth far distant, far below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be a buffler...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's horses, I tell ya...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's them all right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to squirm down the ridge, the others following.

dialogues.speaker: THE SEARCHERS
dialogues.text: Ethan's group crosses to where the other men are waiting  with the horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're camped by the river -- 'bout  twenty miles from here.  Soon's it  gets dark we'll circle out so's to  jump 'em before daybreak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) You're right sure you want to jump  'em, Ethan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin and Brad stare at Sam -- not understanding the  question. But Mose knows what he means and studiously loo into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touch of defiance) It's what we're here for, ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we were trying to get the  girls back -- alive... We jump those  Comanches, they'll kill 'em... You  know that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered, angry) But... but what are we doin' then?... What are we supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I had in mind was runnin' off  their hoss herd... A Comanche on  foot is more apt to be willin' to  listen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes sense to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) What do you know about it?... What's  a quarter-breed Cherokee know about  the Comanche trick of sleeping with  his best pony tied right beside him...  You got as much chance of stampedin'  their herd as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as you have of findin' those girls  alive by ridin' into 'em...  I say  we do it my way, Ethan... and that's  an order!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir... But if you're wrong,  Captain Clayton, don't ever give me  another!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look into each other's eyes a moment, then Sam turns mount... and the others follow. Slowly then they start ri down the slope.

dialogues.speaker: SEARCHERS
dialogues.text: (NOTE: It is now planned to shoot this on sound stage.) Fog and heavy morning mist rise from the swamp. Some catt in the near ground. The effect is eerie, very still excep for the trilling of frogs. Then, very quietly, the men em from the mist swirling around them. They are leading thei horses. Sam looks baffled, angry. They stand still, liste then slowly continue.

dialogues.speaker: FULL SHOT
dialogues.text: (SOUND STAGE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mist is thinning. In the f.g. is a small blackened ar the ashes of a campfire. The men come through the mist -- wary, vigilant. It is Mose who first spots the fire. He r to it and drops beside and feels the ashes. The others come up around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay-he... They was here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sam) SURE!... They WERE here... Now they're  out there... an' waitin' to jump  us!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Clayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got any more orders, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Just keep goin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move on, slowly.

dialogues.speaker: MOVING, (SOUND STAGE)
dialogues.text: The mist is thinning as the men warily move along. Suddenly there is the faint hoot of an owl from behind an to one side... the men turn slightly, hearing it... A mom later another owl hoot, from the same side but up ahead. From the interchange of looks, we must know that the ride are aware of its significance. Mose cups hand to his mout and he hoots in exact imitation of the other calls. Clayt glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in soft apology) Jus' bein' sociable, Cap'n...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan grins wryly. And now the first, faint, ruddy touch the sun hits the slowly moving horsemen and begins to bur through the mist.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: The CAMERA SLOWLY PANS from a sun-touched butte or crag t the file of men slowly walking their horses. An occasiona shred of mist drifts by. Everything about the little cava bespeaks tension, watchfulness. Suddenly -- and every man sees it at the same time -- we see a file of eight Comanc ride slowly out of a canyon at a distance, walking their  horses at the same pace and on a course roughly parallel  with, but slightly converging on, our group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Keep goin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad, who has been looking up ahead, sounds a new warning

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tensely) Look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy!

dialogues.speaker: PAST THE SEARCHERS
dialogues.text: Another Indian file of eight angles out of a different ca and begins to cut in toward the group -- riding slowly, v quietly. Clayton slightly alters course, veering slightly away from the converging files, but still riding slowly. then, from ahead but at a 100 yards, another Comanche gro seems to rise out of the ground and slowly begins closing the gap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Clayton) If you were tryin' to surround 'em,  you sure succeeded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far's the river from here, Mose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been baptized, Reverend... yes  suh, been baptized, thank ye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you better brace yourself for  another one... Ya-HEE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that yell, he drives spurs and cuts sharply at a angle to the converging Indian files -- and every man is  with him. In the next instant, the Comanches whoop and gi chase.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHASE
dialogues.text: with the Ranger group short-cutting in such a way as to  outstrip the Comanche horsemen in a mad dash for the rive

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: Clayton flings his hand up in a signal to halt as the Ran reach the bank. They rein in, wheel their horses and are  reaching for the rifles as the Comanche vanguard races in view -- to find themselves opposed by seven veterans, sit their horses, rifles at their shoulders. The charge breaks as the seven rifles bark, almost in uni and the Indians wheel to shelter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YA-HEE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And once again he spins his mount and takes off, across t river, followed by the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the men pound across.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: They dismount and Charlie and Nesby take the horses and r them to some place of protection as the men group around  Clayton and Ethan. During this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting his orders) This is as good as any... Charlie,  you and Ed take the horses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mose runs over and crouches beside Ethan. Beyond Ethan is Martin, then Brad... Nesby and Charlie will rejoin the gr after an appropriate interval... with all the men shielde behind river boulders, etc.

dialogues.speaker: AND BRAD BEYOND
dialogues.text: Ethan and Mose are hunkered down behind some rocks, very  casual and business-like as they check rifles, set out an carefully wipe cartridges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chattily) Minds me o' the time Joe Powers an'  me fit us some Kiowas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin is in the throes of buck-fever, wiping mouth with  back of his hand, peering anxiously across the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think they mean to charge us,  Uncle Ethan...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...We found us an ole buffler  wallow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring across river) Criminy!

dialogues.speaker: PAST THE GROUP
dialogues.text: On the opposite bank, we see the full force of Comanches  riding into sight -- racing their mounts to the edge, the wheeling off -- jeering, taunting. Brad starts to bring u his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady, Daniel Boone! You don't want  to miss... It makes them think their  medicine's stronger than yours...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay-he... That's jest what I tole Joe  Powers... That un's gettin' kinda  sassy, ain't he, Ethan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One Comanche rides a few yards into the water, brandishin his rifle, taunting the white men. A moment later he is j by a second brave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) Real sassy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Mose slowly bring their rifles to bear -- and then the two shots crack out almost simultaneously. And within split seconds both Comanches fall. The others race away. Sam comes charging over to Ethan and Mose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) I didn't give any order to fire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, Captain... I don't  need any formal invitation to kill a  Comanch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) You got one now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he drops behind a rock as, with a wild whooping, the  Comanche forces swing from their places of hiding and hit the river. The men open fire, all but Martin, who has fro staring wild-eyed at the oncoming Comanches.

dialogues.speaker: THE DEFENDERS
dialogues.text: Brad, Charlie, Clayton, Nesby are snapping shot after sho Only Martin seems out of it. Ethan shoots him a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slack your shoulders... Slack 'em...  Your hands'll take care of  themselves...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the tension leaves Martin. Somehow his gun is in  position and he is firing as fast and well as the others.

dialogues.speaker: INDIAN CHARGE
dialogues.text: The Comanches are coming in, crouched low over their poni necks, whooping and firing. Men and horses go down, count off by the expert marksmanship of the Texans. But they ke coming.

dialogues.speaker: PAST MARTIN, ETHAN, MO
dialogues.text: They drop their rifles now and pull out revolvers for clo range work. One Comanche breaks through from the side, hi buffalo lance ready for the thrust. Ethan whirls and fire The Comanche horse charges through the defense line and o and there is a muffled scream of pain from Ed Nesby.

dialogues.speaker: THE INDIANS
dialogues.text: The charge breaks and Comanches wheel left and right, rac back across the river. With magnificent horsemanship, one brave rides to an unhorsed warrior crouched in the shallo and swings him up behind. Two others, riding together, he for one of the two dead Comanches Ethan and Mose had down on their first shots. Swinging simultaneously from their  saddles, they grab the dead man and carry him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cackling) There goes yer scalp, Ethan!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan snuggles his rifle to his shoulder as two other rac Comanches prepare to pick up the other dead Indian. Most the Comanches have regained the far bank now and are raci away. The firing from the Texans has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still got one out there.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND ETHAN
dialogues.text: The angle is along his rifle barrel as it beads on one of the racing Comanches trying to pick up the dead Indian. Clayton's big hand grasps the rifle barrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) No, Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO
dialogues.text: Ethan looks up into Clayton's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let them bury their dead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan pulls the gun free and looks out across the river.

dialogues.speaker: PAST THEM
dialogues.text: The Comanches have done their work, are riding away -- an over the saddle of one lies the limp form of the dead Ind Ethan looks back at Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That tears it, Reverend... From now  on, you keep out... (mad now -- facing  the others) All of you!... I don't want you with  me... I don't need you... for what I  got to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) No need to shout, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA SWINGS to pick up the figure of Nesby outstret on the ground, writhing in pain; with Charlie kneeling be him. The men cross to stand around the fallen man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reckon we got to go back -- Ed's  shoulder is smashed -- bad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can make it... just get me on a  horse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No good, Ed... And Ethan's right...   This is a job for a company of  Rangers... or it's a job for one or  two men... Right now we're too many...  an' not enough...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (facing Ethan) Only one way you can stop me lookin'  for Lucy, mister... An' that's kill  me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how I feel, Uncle Ethan... (correcting the slip) Ethan, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan glares at them, but has to accept it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right... but I'm givin' the  orders... You take 'em or we split  up here and now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Why, sure, Ethan... There's just the  one thing we're after... finding  Deborah and Lucy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly -- turning  away) If they're still alive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads away, for his horse. Brad and Martin look at eac other as the full import of Ethan's footnote strikes home Then they head for their own horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan, Martin, and Brad mount. Clayton crosses to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You boys got enough shells?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaya con dios.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three re-enter the river and slowly start across, wit Clayton gravely looking after them. The three riders cont across the river... and the Search Theme resumes.

dialogues.speaker: DESERT COUNTRY
dialogues.text: A region of buttes and giant rock formations; treeless, a and seemingly reaching out to infinity. Far off we see a  cloud of dust -- miles and miles off. Only the dust, noth else. From behind CAMERA ride the three men -- Ethan, Bra and Martin -- dust-powdered, eyes bloodshot. The three ar watching that distant cloud of dust. They force their wea horses onward.

dialogues.speaker: LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: The ANGLE is past some spectacular butte or citadel of ro into another long reach of valley -- different from the f view of it, yet alike in its suggestion of endlessness. But now there is no cloud of dust far away -- nothing to  suggest the passage of anything but time itself. Ethan, Martin, and Brad ride into the fringe of the butte shadow and scan the terrain ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrill) They got to stop sometime... if  they're human at all, they got to  stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw... a human man rides a horse  till it dies... then he goes on  afoot... A Comanche comes along...  gets that horse up... and rides it  twenty more miles... Then he eats  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan turns to catch Martin thirstily drinking from his  canteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Easy on that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry... We don't even know if Debbie  'n Lucy are with this bunch... Maybe  they split up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're with 'em -- if they're still  alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad wheels on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've said that enough!... Maybe  Lucy's dead... maybe they're both  dead... but if I hear it from you  again, I'll fight ya, Mr. Edwards!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an aside) That'll be the day!... Let's ride.

dialogues.speaker: LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: (NOTE: This is the gap in the rocks near the "Medicine  Country" at Monument.) The three riders come to where the trail they have been  following forks... the main horseprint track leading ahea a lesser track heading for a narrow gap between two butte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four of 'em cut out here... Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan thinks he knows why. His face is bleak. But he trie to be casual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take a look... You keep after  the others...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns his mount toward the gap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) You want us to fire a shot if...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgustedly) No... nor build bonfires... nor beat  drums neither. I'll meet you on the  far side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still grumbling as he rides off. An abashed Martin r ahead along the broad trail with Brad. (NOTE: Ethan's serape, tied behind his saddle, should be  clearly seen as he rides away -- not pointed up, but visi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin and Brad, riding in a direction opposite to that i which they had taken off -- indicating their circle route haul up momentarily as they spot Ethan, standing beside h horse, his back to them, some distance along. They turn  slightly off their course and ride out toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan turns, almost startled, as the two youths ride in. His serape is no longer behind his saddle. Ethan looks at them blankly for a minute -- as though not really seeing  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... it's you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a vague gesture) I... uh... here's where they met up  again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both can see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) Trail leads off there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at him and each other -- for these are clearly  unnecessary remarks and doubly surprising coming from Eth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd they break off? (no answer) Was there water in that canyon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh...?  No... no water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right, Ethan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh...? (more like his usual  gruff self) Sure I'm all right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to his horse, mounts. Martin is right beside him he notes the missing serape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say!... What happened to your blanket?  Lose it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must've... Anyway, I ain't goin'  back to look for it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
