dialogues.text: He leads out. Brad rides up beside Martin. Again the two  exchange puzzled looks. Martin shrugs and the three conti along the broad trace of the Indian ponies into the setti sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan crouches over a small fire built into a slit trench that barely the glow of the flames can be seen. Beyond hi Martin is leading their unsaddled horses away. The men ha come to the end of another long day. Both men look up as  Brad comes over a hill slope and rides recklessly down th incline to their camp. His horse is lathered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting it) I saw her!... I saw Lucy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin runs to his side as Brad slides off his mount. Ethan moves more slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) They're camped 'bout two miles over... I was just swingin' back when I saw  their smoke... I bellied up a ridge  an' they was right below me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see Debbie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I saw Lucy all right... She  was wearin' that blue dress... an'  she was walkin' along...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice flat) What you saw wasn't Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was, I tell you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you saw was a buck wearin' Lucy's dress... (they stare at him) I found Lucy back there in that  canyon... I wrapped her in my blanket  an' buried her with m'own hands... I  thought it best to keep it from you --  long as I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't look at Brad or at Martin. Brad can't speak -- a then finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they...? Was she...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan wheels on him in shouting fury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blazing) What've I got to do -- draw you a  picture?... Spell it out?... Don't  ever ask me!... Long as you live  don't ever ask me more!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad wipes his mouth with the back of his hand. He turns walking stiff-legged as though on stilts back to his hors He bends his head against the saddle, as though to hide h grief. Martin turns away from him and walks back to Ethan And in that moment, Brad mounts and takes off in the same direction from which he had ridden in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frantically) BRAD!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They run for their horses.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He comes pounding down a slope, and he takes off his hat skims it away. He rips off a neckerchief as though to rel the rush of raging blood.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He reaches the crest and reins in. A distant firelight is his face. He takes one moment to look down into the Coman camp o.s. Then he has his gun out. His eyes are wild, his face wet with sweat. Then he throws back his head and he  yells -- and with the yell goes charging into the camp.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN AND MARTIN
dialogues.text: They rein in -- staring -- as from afar they hear Brad's  yell echoing and bouncing off the canyon walls. There is  nothing they can do. They hear his shouts, then the quick bark of his .44, and the angry shouts of the Comanche.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: His face is red with the reflected light of the fires he passing o.s. and his eyes are alight with a crazy, savage joy. His gun cracks once, then again -- and the hammer cl on a spent shell.

dialogues.speaker: SCAR
dialogues.text: He stands apart, warbow drawn and arrow notched. He relea it at his running target. We hear its impact and a high g of pain... and then the jubilant, yammering yells of othe Comanches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The distant yammering of the Comanches doesn't quite drow out one stifled scream of pain; we can surmise a scalping knife was busy in the last instance of Brad's life. Marti slumps in his saddle. Ethan listens a moment, then turns Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just hope he took some with  him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns his horse back the way they had come. Martin sta at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you goin' to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get some sleep... Tomorrow's another  day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, he rides away. Slowly, reluctantly but helpless t do otherwise, Martin follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A study of horseprints etched in the soil -- the mark of passage of many horses; perhaps an eagle or turkey feathe fallen from a warbonnet. And then we hear and see the app of two plodding horses, and the dusty boots of the horsem Ethan and Martin -- following the trail. The Search Theme resumes and continues over the next three shots, helping suggest the passage of time, the change of scene.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN AND MARTIN
dialogues.text: The two figures are little more than specks in a vastness savage country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again we study the hooves of two horses, fighting their w up a rocky slope and past a thorn bush on which -- flutte in the mountain wind -- is a torn scrap of scarlet cloth  with a bit of beadwork or Indian decoration.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: It is a portrait study of two faces -- etched by wind and privation and cold into tragic, fanatic masks. Martin has aged years in a matter of months. Falling snow flakes touch their faces and begin to rime their stubbly  beards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Say it. We're beat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) No... our turnin' back don't change  anything... not in the long run. If  she's alive, she's safe... for a  while... They'll keep her to raise  as one of their own, 'til she's of  an age to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns his mount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you think we got a chance to  find her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Injun will chase a thing til he  thinks he's chased it enough... Then  he quits... Same when he runs...  Seems he never learns there's such a  thing as a critter that might just  keep comin' on... So we'll find them  in the end, I promise you that...  We'll find them just as sure as the  turning of the earth.

dialogues.speaker: TWILIGHT
dialogues.text: The time is spring. It is a year and a half later. The Jorgensen house is larger than the Edwards place -- o sod and logs, with a covered breezeway connecting the two separate buildings of the house: one being the keeping ro the other the sleeping quarters of the numerous Jorgensen brood. A meadowlark breaks into his sudden song. A dog or two come barking around the side of the house as Ethan an Martin ride slowly from behind CAMERA toward the house. I that instant a lamp is lighted within the house and Lars  Jorgensen comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR DOOR
dialogues.text: Jorgensen peers at the two men as they ride up - recogniz them, of course, but ill-prepared for the change in their appearance and full of unspoken questions. Bearing a lamp, Mrs. Jorgensen hurries out to stand besid her husband -- and her face works and tears begin to well her eyes. Two tow-headed boys -- 13 or 14 -- come after h Jorgensen makes a little signal with one hand, not even  looking at the boys, and they hurry out to take the reins Ethan and Martin dismount.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN AND MARTIN
dialogues.text: The passage of time has stamped Martin -- and will contin during our story more and more to stamp him -- in the ima of Ethan. Now it may show only in the set of his hat or t of standing; later it will be in his walk, in his speech paucity of speech). Neither man is sure of his reception. They are thinking of Brad -- dead because of their search and Martin is thinking of Laurie. And then Mrs. Jorgensen running across to Martin and has him in her arms as thoug he were her son -- saying nothing, just holding him. He s frozen a moment and then he returns the embrace. Ethan wa a moment, then crosses to Jorgensen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jorgensen) You got my letter about your son,  Brad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah... Just about this time a year  ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It came the day before his...   birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord giveth--the Lord taketh  away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jorgensen starts to lead the way inside. Martin hang back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't fit to go indoors, miz  Jorgensen... These clothes is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurie rushes past her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him hard and full on the mouth -- and has no e for anyone else. Mrs. Jorgensen looks on with amusement.  Martin is just bowled over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing) And him probably forgettin' all about  you!... Probably can't even call  your name to mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Laurie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Laurie smiles triumphantly at her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) But I fairly forgot just how pretty  you was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurie grabs his hand then and pulls him indoors -- and t is no further resistance from Martin. Mrs. Jorgensen and her husband converge then on Ethan -- her face is gravely questioning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little one?... Debbie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan shakes his head. She squeezes his arm reassuringly they start indoors.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: This is a room off the kitchen end of the keeping room -- and described in the book as the "grandmother room": with narrow, slit-like windows, a set of single bunk beds, pos a fireplace. Martin is in a deep wooden tub, taking a hot bath, curryi his back with a long-handled brush. Beyond him is the doo It opens and Martin turns casually -- and at once stops b casual as Laurie enters and purposefully crosses to a sto or bench on which his discarded clothing is scattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... What you doin'...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up the shirt, puts it over one arm; she reaches for his long-handled and ragged underwear, runs a fist th a hole in its seat, clucks and shreds it into rags. Durin this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a yelp) Don't go takin' that stuff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't worth the mendin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and looks at him, matter of fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you gettin' red-in-the-face  for?... I have brothers, haven't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I ain't one of 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a woman, Martie... (he tries to say  something but she  goes right on) We wash and mend your dirty clothes  all our lives... When you're little  we even wash you... How a man can  ever make out to get bashful in front  of a woman I'll never know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk like a feller might just as  leave run around nekkid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't bother me... (she heads for the  door) I wouldn't try it in front of pa,  though, was I you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she is laughing as she closes the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a plastered room, everything bright and shiny; a bi wood-burning cookstove, above it a row of shiny copper po the furniture handmade and probably not too much unlike t good plain Swedish modern of today. There should be Scandinavian accents in the decor. All to a cheerful, warm-smelling room. Ethan is talking as Laurie enters the room still carrying Martin's shirt, the rags of his underwear. She will wait, listening for a break in what Ethan is saying, to try to her mother's attention. Jorgensen is sitting in his usual chair -- with his boots off, puffing his pipe more or les in tune with what Ethan is talking about. Mrs. Jorgensen in her rocker, darning or knitting. Ethan is standing nea the mantel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...an' then it snowed and we lost  the trail... No need to tell ya all  the places we went... Fort Richardson,  Fort Wingate an' Cobb... the Anadarko  Agency... Trouble is we don't even  know which band that war party  belonged to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jorgensen looks up from her darning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you did all a body could, Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got your boy killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Don't go blamin' yourself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) It's this country killed my boy!...  Yes, by golly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jorgensen stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Lars!... It so happens we be  Texicans... We took a reachin' hold,  way far out, past where any man has  right or reason to hold on... Or if  we didn't, our folks did... So we  can't leave off without makin' them  out to be fools, wastin' their lives  'n wasted in the way they died... A  Texican's nothin' but a human man  out on a limb... This year an' next  and maybe for a hundred more.  But I  don't think it'll be forever.  Someday  this country will be a fine good  place to be... Maybe it needs our  bones in the ground before that time  can come...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The speech impresses everyone but Laurie, who probably ha heard a word of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma!... Martie's drawers is a sight!   Ain't fit for rags!... Would it be  all right if we gave him some of  Brad's things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is just the briefest hesitation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why...'course it would! They're in  the chest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she leads the way briskly, with Laurie following, to big chest at the far end of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising excitedly) By golly, the letter... In the chest,  mama... It came for you, Ethan...   last winter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan and Jorgensen cross together to where Mrs. Jorgense is raising the top of a huge dower chest. She extracts a  letter, wrapped in oilskin against moths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Joab Wilkes of the Rangers brought  it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan takes the letter and studies it very carefully befo venturing to open it. Jorgensen is quite curious, but try not to seem nosy. The women remain at the chest -- pullin out various folded garments, etc. Finally Ethan carefully opens it and takes out a letter -- dirty as to paper, cru printed in pencil and with a horseshoe nail pinning a two inch square snip of calico to the bottom of the sheet. He reads the letter with the habitual difficulty of a man un to words and then he turns the letter, removes the nail a looks at the snip of cloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Mrs. Jorgensen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes to him, her arms piled with clothing; and Laurie a step behind her, holding up a new pair of long- handled underwear -- measuring it with her eyes for holes etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you look at this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out the snip of calico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why it's just a snip of calico...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever see it before... like mebbe  on a dress Debbie wore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!... Yes, I remember!... Have  they found her, Ethan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... not yet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the calico snip, places it within the letter and carefully pockets it. He looks broodingly into the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...not yet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurie's face is troubled as she turns from him and heads for the grandmother room, carrying the armful of clothes.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Martin is sitting sulkily on a cot, wrapped in a blanket. He glares up as Laurie enters. His feet are in his boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might at least have left me my pants!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shush!... Time for bed anyway... (putting clothes near  him) Likely these'll need some takin'  in... Oh, Martie, you're that gaunted!  ...Ma's havin' a turkey for dinner  tomorrow and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Laurie!... Come... come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan opens the door, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Pa!... Good night, Martie...   good night, Mr. Edwards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants to kiss Martie but is shy in Ethan's presence a hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night... Laurie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin stoops to remove his boots. Ethan studies him and  looks thoughtfully after the girl and at Martin. He takes the letter out of his pocket -- as though he mea to read it -- and then he puts it back decisively. He starts to undress. Martin lies back on his bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jorgensen's been runnin' his cattle  with my own...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring) YOUR cattle?... DEBBIE'S cattle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan returns the stare without any change of expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's agreed to take you on and share  the increase from my herd while I'm  gone... I'll be pushin' on tomorrow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't stayin'... I set out lookin'  for Debbie... I aim to keep on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's my... my...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's your nothin'... She's no kin  to you at all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always felt like she was... Her  folks takin' me in, raisin' me like  one of their own...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That don't make 'em kin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right... I ain't got no kin...   I'm goin' to keep lookin' that's  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? You got any horses, or money to  buy 'em... You ain't even got money  to buy cartridges... Jorgensen's  offering you a good livin' here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin throws himself back, turns his face to the wall. Ethan looks soberly at him -- and is sorry for the brutal of his words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin... I want you to know  somethin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning -- mad as  hell) Yeah... you want me to know I ain't  got no kin -- no money -- no horses --  nothing but a dead man's clothes to  wear!... You tole me that already...   Now shut your head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: DAWN LIGHT
dialogues.text: It is a still scene, with the first light of day in the s a thin plume of smoke rising from the chimney.

dialogues.speaker: DAWN LIGHT
dialogues.text: She is in a robe made of an Indian blanket, belted snugly around her waist. She wears moccasins for slippers. Her  flannel nightgown is high at the collar and almost trails the floor. She is at the stove, frying bacon and eggs; a  coffee pot is on the boil. Beyond her the door to the  grandmother room opens and Martin comes in -- dressed in  Brad's clothes. His eyes whip around the room. Laurie doe turn as he slowly approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Ethan rode on... an hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The starch goes out of him. He walks heavily to the table and sits, slumped. She looks at him compassionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you can do about  finding Debbie that he can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just shakes his head, not looking at her. She lifts th food from the skillet onto a plate and sets it before him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll find her now, Martie... Please  believe me... I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head. She crosses to the stove for the coff pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what scares me -- him findin'  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it is her turn to stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurie, I've seen his eyes when he  so much as hears the word 'Comanche'  ...I've seen him take his knife an'  ...never mind... But he's a man can  go crazy wild... It might come on  him when it was the worst thing could  be... What I counted on, I hoped to  be there to stop him, if such thing  come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurie has poured his coffee. Now he sips it. She sits at the table with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) I hoped I could hold you here... But  I guess I knew... So I stole this  for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes Ethan's letter from her breast and hands it to  him. He takes it, puzzled, and slowly reads it aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'I bought a small size dress off a  Injun... If this here is a piece of  yr chiles dress bring reward. I know  where they gone... Jerem Futterman.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin is on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) Futterman!... He's got a little  tradin' post on the South Fork o'  the Brazos... Laurie, I just got to  get me a good horse! Think yer pa  would...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finish your breakfast...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta catch up with him, Laurie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost in tears --  but angry) Go on then! Pa's in the barn saddlin'  the Fort Worth stud... an' you can  take the light gelding with the  blaze...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's Sweet-face -- your own  good horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurie goes to the front door and throws it wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hysterically) Take it and welcome... but don't  count on finding me here when you  get back... I've been dallying around  this god-forsaken wind-scour almost  two long years waitin' for you... I  ain't cut out to be an old maid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (miserably) I can't help it, Laurie... I just  gotta catch up with Ethan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs out and she slams the door, then rests her head  against it.

dialogues.speaker: EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jorgensen quietly enters the room and sees Laurie wi head pressed against the door. She wants to offer some wo of sympathy, but doesn't know what to say. She crosses to the stove to pour herself a cup of coffee. Then we hear t drum of horses' hooves, the sound of Martin riding away. Laurie flings open the door, almost as though to call him back.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: ANGLING from behind Laurie in the doorway as Martin, ridi one horse, leading another, goes galloping away.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Low, squat adobe structure, with a crudely lettered sign- board proclaiming it: 'JEREM. FUTTERMAN, TRADER'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are adjacent outbuildings and corral. Four horses a tied outside, two being pack animals. A surly-looking whi man or breed sits in a stool tilted back near the door,  whittling with a long-bladed knife, eyeing the horses  covetously. He glances aside and glares as a squaw shuffl along bearing a clumsy load of faggots on her bowed back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andale! Andale!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fearfully she quickens her step. The man gets up, shoves  knife into belt and heads into the post.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: It is a grimy establishment with some dusty trade goods o shelves; a counter which serves as a bar; a few plank tab and benches. The breed seen outside enters and crosses to a side table where another mean-looking hombre sits preparing to play game of solitaire with a deck of limp cards. Ethan and Martin are at a table in the center of the room examining a dirty, rumpled child's dress -- Debbie's. Martin nods soberly in answer to Ethan's inquiring look;  yes, it's hers. Both look up as FUTTERMAN crosses from th bar, carrying a whisky jug and two dirty glasses -- his  fingers thrust inside the glasses. Futterman is a squaw m and a killer -- dead eyes in a white face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sets the jug down, picks up one of the glasses -- so g and thumb-printed it is almost opaque. Both Ethan and Mar regard it with disgust. Futterman gives a slight shrug, t the dress and starts to wipe the dirty glass with it. Mar snatches it out of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) How'd you come by this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said there'd be a thousand dollar  reward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan looks at him and beyond toward the two men.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO PLUG-UGLIES
dialogues.text: The solitaire player has a card in mid-air -- frozen,  watching. The other man has the same buzzard-watchful loo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reward'll be paid when I find her --  an' if she's alive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Futterman uncorks the jug, prepares to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man's got a right to expect some  kind o' payment... I laid out for  the dress an' sendin' you the  writin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tilts the jug to his mouth as Ethan reaches for his he leather pouch. Futterman watches greedily as Ethan lets a gold piece slide out. He tosses it onto the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty Yankee dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Futterman puts the jug down. His hand inches -- as though pulled by a magnet -- toward the gold piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...an' a man's time is worth  somethin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan's big hand clamps over Futterman's and he starts  squeezing as a man would squeeze a lemon. Futterman's lip whiten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young buck fetched it in late last  summer... (Ethan eases the grip) Said it belonged to a captive chile  of Chief Scar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scar? Never heard of any Chief Scar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither... But this buck claimed  he was a big war chief with the  Nawyecky Comanches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scar's band was headin' north... to  winter in at Fort Wingate... eatin'  agency beef. That's what this buck  said... Maybe he lied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And maybe you lie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case you won't find her -- and I won't get my thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan stands. Martin follows. Martin takes the dress and  folds it carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (too casually) Stay the night if you want... (Ethan shakes his  head) Cards?... A jug?... If you'd like  some company, we got a few squaws on  the place...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan and Martin head for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two plug-uglies stand -- mean ready to do their maste bidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget to come back with my  thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't yours yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They leave. The CAMERA holds on Futterman as he slowly ru his bruised hand. His henchmen drift toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slight smile) Bad manners... He shoulda said 'good- bye.'

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: They have set up camp near a cluster of cottonwoods to wh the horses have been tied. One of the horses is restless, possibly nickering. Ethan strokes its neck, looking out  thoughtfully into the night -- listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acts like somethin's out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heading toward  campfire) Smells a change in the weather...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS him to where Martin is spreading his blanket  some little distance from the small fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't surprise me if we didn't  have a frost 'fore mornin'... Here... (he picks up a saddle  and puts it close to  fire) Whyn't you bed down closer to the  fire, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin is a bit surprised as Ethan takes the blanket and  spreads it near the saddle -- making the saddle serve as pillow. Then Ethan tosses a few more heavy pieces of dry  wood on the fire, making it blaze up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! What's the idea...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm gettin' like Mose Harper --  my bones is cold tonight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spreads his own blanket as Martin wraps into his bedro and when Martin turns, he casually arranges the blanket t suggest it is over the figure of a man. During this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny... When we passed through Fort  Wingate last winter, we didn't hear  mention of any Nawyecky Comanche  there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan steps back -- and studies the "dummy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so funny... if you recollect  what 'Nawyecka' means...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan studies Martin's back -- the light on him -- and lo around figuring the range of fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorta like 'roundabout' -- like a  man says he's goin' one place when  he means to go just the reverse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drowsily) Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all settled an' comfortable now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin just grunts and snugs deeper into his blanket. Eth nods his satisfaction -- sure Martin isn't going to chang positions. Then he takes off his hat and boots and uses t to complete the dummy. He picks up his rifle then and qui walks out of the camp.

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: Three shadowy figures -- Futterman and his two henchmen - are quietly dismounting, taking rifles from saddle scabba At a hand signal from Futterman, they quietly fan out afo

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: still snug in his blankets, sound asleep; the fire burnin little lower but still shedding plenty of light on him.

dialogues.speaker: HIS HENCHMEN
dialogues.text: At a crouch or crawling, the three worm their way among s rocks until they reach a slight rise looking down into th camp. Martin is asleep and next to him is Ethan's dummy, over its face, and the fire still burning. The two henchm snake their rifles up to a firing position. A shot cracks and one man is knocked flat on his face. The other whirls in the direction of the shot, his rifle  swinging in search of a target. A second shot splits the  night and the breed falls as though hit by a giant fist.. Martin is sitting up now, staring wildly around. Futterma starts to run down-slope, away from the hidden marksman,  dodging between the rocks. A third shot catches him in th back and he spins and falls and rolls down the slope into the firepit camp area. Martin is on his feet now.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He is staring at Futterman, face down and almost at his f He looks around in fear at someone approaching -- hand go to his gun. Then he relaxes as Ethan casually enters the  camp, bareheaded, carrying his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks... you did just fine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan kneels beside Futterman, turns him over, reaches in his pockets -- first one, then another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dazed) Futterman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just couldn't wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching him go  through pockets) Whatchu doin'?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan grins satisfiedly as he straightens and spins the g piece in the air, catches it and pockets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even got my twenty dollars back... We did all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now Martin is getting the whole picture... and he's m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE?... You just used me for bait -- staked me out like a... buildin' up  the fire... fixin' it so's... I coulda  had my brains blowed out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan is just grinning at him -- completely unruffled, de none of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explosively) Suppose you'd missed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan sobers a little, seems honestly surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never occurred to me...

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: It is a day in early winter. Charlie MacCorry, short-coat is galloping across the yard as Jorgensen crosses it --  carrying a load of firewood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling it) Howdy, Mister Jorgensen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacCorry swings off his saddle near the porch, as the doo opens and Mrs. Jorgensen comes out -- shawled against the cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a letter here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jorgensen lets the cordwood drop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By golly! A letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Miss Laurie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Charlie, come in... (calling inside) LAURIE!... My land!... Two letters  in the one year!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Charlie enters, following Mrs. Jorgensen. Jorgensen  excitedly enters and closes the door. Laurie comes in fro another room. Charlie smiles and bows clumsily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Laurie) A letter for you, Laurie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes'm... Figgered it might be the  news you been waitin' for... so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the letter to Laurie who comes over eagerly, tak it and studies the wrapper before opening it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real good o' you to ride all the way  over, Charlie... Might at least say  your thank you's, Laurie... Declare!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Laurie has no interest in anything but the letter whi she is reading skimmingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (expectantly) Yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurie! Don't keep a body just  standin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurie looks up then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) I was just readin' to see if...  Anyway, it's MY letter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agreeably) 'Course it is. Now let's all get  comfortable an' set so's we can listen  while Laurie reads her letter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning as if to go) Maybe I'd better be goin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay, Charlie... After all,  Charlie brought the letter, Laurie...  He got a right to listen too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jorgensen has been pulling and pushing chairs around and now they all take places. Jorgensen automatically rea for his glasses on the mantel and puts them on -- even th he isn't going to read the letter. Laurie has been sneaki looks at some of the other pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surrendering) Oh, all right!  Well... Martin says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the beginning...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Dear Miss Laury'... He spells it  with a Y instead of an I... E...  Wouldn't you think he'd know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares what he spells it? Read  the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Miss Laury... I take pen in  hand to let you know Ethan and me  still are trying to catch up with  them Comanches the late Mister  Futterman told us about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breaks off, looks up -- puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The late Mister Futterman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That means Mister Futterman is dead,  by golly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonder what happened to the poor  man.  Go on, Laurie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resuming the letter) We cut north through Indian territory  and... (her voice fades)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SILENT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: leading their pack animals. Martin's voice picks up the  narration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon we was meeting up with Kiowas  an' Wichitas an' even some Comanches  camped by one of the agencies...

dialogues.speaker: FALL WEATHER, (SILENT)
dialogues.text: The camp is on the outskirts of a trading post. Indians w unsmilingly from tepees, or in little clusters afoot; a f mounted braves ride on parallel courses as Ethan and Mart ride through camp toward the post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But none of them was Nawyecky's nor  claimed to know a war chief named  Scar... He's the one the late Mister  Futterman said had Debbie...

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: This trading post is in marked contrast to Futterman's -- being well-stocked, clean and presided over by HIRAM APPL a resolute, clean-looking man of middle years. Ethan and Martin -- in winter garb -- are being shown a  variety of trade goods, including a shoebox full of ornat ribbon rosettes, such as are awarded animals at stock fai Appleby is solemnly affirming the trade value of these, a well as sleeve garters, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At one o' the agencies we outfitted  with all kind an' manner of trade  goods... figgerin' that'd make it  easier for us to come an' go... You'd  laugh if I told you what was our  biggest seller...

dialogues.speaker: INDIAN
dialogues.text: Ethan is ceremoniously pinning something on the stern-fac buck. It is one of the rosettes seen in the shoebox. CAMERA MOVES to an extreme CLOSEUP of the rosette. On it, gold letters, is:

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: As the Indian proudly steps back, we see beyond him a hal dozen other braves -- all rosetted. Ethan looks them over complacently while Martin -- to hide the smile that threa to split his face -- bends to pick up a huge bundle of fu

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING LAURIE
dialogues.text: reading the letter. She is at the bottom of a page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'There is one other thing I got to  tell you before you hear it from  Ethan... How I got myself a wife'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops and stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WIFE?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at them - dazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delightedly) He did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smacking his knee --  very happy indeed) Good! A young man should get married  early in life. Right, mama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jorgensen, full of sympathy for Laurie, just glares her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every young man should at least  once...Go on, Laurie! Read!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (haltingly) A little Comanche squaw - SQUAW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that she crumples the letter and throws it into fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aghast) Laurie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jorgensen is out of his chair and scrambling in the firep to recover the letter. He fetches it out, beating the spa out. The letter is basically undamaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sternly) Is no way to treat a letter, Laurie  ...Mama maybe you better read it... (to Charlie, proudly) My wife was a school teacher, Charlie  ...She reads good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurie snatches the letter back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll read it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie crosses the room, picks up a guitar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smugly) So he married a Comanche squaw...  Haw haw haw!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurie glares at him. He begins chording the guitar.

dialogues.speaker: FALL OR EARLY WINTER
dialogues.text: "LOOK" is somewhat under five feet tall, pigeon-toed, pla faced and wide-eyed. Over her arm is a very handsome blan She is coming forward shyly toward Martin, propelled by a Comanche -- her father. Martin, with an armful of trade g a few yards of bright calico, a couple of AGED SOW rosett and some trinkets -- is indicating the blanket. Look glan shyly at her father. He shakes his head negatively. Look is disappointed. The father points to Martin's pile of trade goods. Martin bends and picks up the indicated object: it is a battered high-crowned beaver hat. The Indian grunts his approval a puts it on. Look looks relieved. Martin reaches for the  blanket. Look takes a quick step backward and holds up on finger: wait! Then she runs back through the other Comanc now crowding forward.

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING ETHAN
dialogues.text: who rides in slowly, leading their pack horse and Martin' horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Let's go... I think I stumbled onto  somethin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Scar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name registers with some of the nearer braves. There a quick interchange of glances, frowning, hostile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) When are you goin' to learn to keep  your mouth shut! Come on.  Let's get  out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I just bought a good blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curtly) Forget it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin mounts and the two ride out. The Comanches stare a them suspiciously, resentfully.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: They are riding down a slight grade beyond which (we can  assume) is the Comanche camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I heard back there was that a  band o' hostile Nawyeckas came through  this way less'n two weeks ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Think it might be...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks and both turn as Look rides over the hill on a  little spotted Indian pony, with her squaw-bag slung up b her and her blanket over the saddle. She closes the gap  between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she followin' for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look smiles shyly at Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I changed my mind... You can  keep your blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures for her to go back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares and then dutifully wheels her horse. Martin an Ethan face front again. Look wheels her horse again and i right with them. Martin stops - exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look... you don't understand... (he waves her away) I don't want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look just sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explosively) YOU don't understand, ya chunkhead!   You didn't buy any blanket! Ya bought  her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aghast) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got yourself a wife, sonny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a wail) Oh no! Tell her she's got to go  back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And have her whole family after our  scalps for floutin' one o' their  women?... No sir! Come on, Mrs.  Pauley...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look smiles and sets her horse in motion as Ethan moves a Martin's face is a mask of comic despair as he gives up. is mouthing the words --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs... Pauley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Ethan suddenly breaks into song; to the tune of "Skip My Lou:"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) I got another gal purtier'n you.  I  got another gal purtier'n you.  I  got another gal purtier'n you.  Skip  to my Lou, my darlin'.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Ethan is wrapped in his blanket roll, head propped by an  elbow, grinning sardonically as he watches a strange ritu in the camp. The score is softly reprising "Skip to my Lo

dialogues.speaker: PAST ETHAN
dialogues.text: Look is standing with her blanket folded over one arm, he head shyly downcast, not far from where Martin (back to h is spreading his own bed roll. He sits on it then and beg pulling off his boots. He is very conscious of Ethan's  watchful scrutiny. Finally he is ready. He lies back on h blanket. At once Look is at his side to spread her own  blanket. Martin sits bolt upright and tugs his blanket fr and wraps it protectively around him. She stares at him,  puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water!... (in Comanche) Pah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods her understanding, hurries off to fetch a cantee Martin glares at Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way to train 'em. Looks  like Mrs. Pauley's goin' to make you  a fine beautiful wife...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it out, will ya...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look returns with the canteen, hands it to Martin and kne beside him. He looks at her sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look... I wish I could explain to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now Look speaks for the first time. She indicates her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now she jabbers in Comanche and, at the appropriate time, will point to the sky and imitate a bird flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay tzare T'sala-ta-komal-ta-name...   unt kang-yah Look. (which means) (My father calls me Wild Goose Flying  in the Night Sky... but you call me  'Look').

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin looks blank, but Ethan chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says her name's Wild Goose Flying in  the Night Sky... but she'll answer  to Look since it pleases ya...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blankly) Look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods and smiles and quickly settles alongside him and spreads her blanket over them both. Martin recoils, plant his foot in the small of her back and sends her sprawling Ethan busts a gut laughing. Martin jumps to his feet, ang

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hotly) I don't think it's so funny... If  you want to do some good, whyn't you  ask her where Scar is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan stares at the girl. Her face is suddenly impassive she looks from Martin to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) She heard ya-all right... An' she  knows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets to his feet and he crosses to stand before her. S does Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unt osupanet cah-nay Scar? (meaning) (You know where Scar  is?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares sullenly, not answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ask her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! (she faces him) Scar?... (sign talk) Do you know where he went? And if he  has a girl with him... a white girl --  nai-bist pabo taibo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands... She indicates Martin. She indicates herself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mah nee-koo-ur? (meaning) (Your woman?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking head) No... not my wife... My... (to Ethan) How do you say sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Comanche) Nami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks gravely from Ethan to Martin. Then, with impass face, she bends swiftly, picks up her blanket and walks a from them to choose her own sleeping place. The two men d know what to make of it.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: It is the same scene the following morning. The men are  standing above where Look had bedded for the night, looki at the ground. Clearly marked on the hard ground is a cru drawn arrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beats me how she could get that pony  out o' camp without neither of us  hearin' a thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ain't goin' back to her family,  that's certain... not if she took  off where the arrow points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think she means for us to follow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How should I know... She's YOUR wife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks toward their horses, starts to saddle up. Martin follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think maybe we oughta...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hiding a grin) Yeah, I kinda figgered you'd say  that... Bein' a new husband and all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Ethan starts singing "Skip to My Lou" half under his  breath. Martin gives him a sour side-glance and continues saddling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jorgensen is bringing a lighted lamp over to the tab where Laurie is reading against the fading light of day.  Jorgensen's pipe has gone out and he lights it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she left other signs for us to  follow but we'll never know -- 'cause  it snowed all day and all the next  week... We were heading north, through  the buffalo country when something  happened that I ain't got straight  in my own mind yet... (her voice fades)

dialogues.speaker: FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: The two men are picking their way through a snow-mantled  grove. Martin's voice resumes the narration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan's always been throwing it up  to me that I'm a quarter-breed... I  never figgered it made much  difference...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this day we came on a small herd.  We needed some meat so we circled  'round...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and came up on 'em afoot...  They  hadn't been hunted, so it was no  trick workin' in close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men walk from behind CAMERA. Ethan aims, fires an brings down a bull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan got a nice one on his first  shot, but then he began killing one  after another -- cows as well as  bulls -- fast as he could fire and  load... It was just a slaughter...  no sense to it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shots cracking out -- the terrified bawling of the bulls the beginning of the stampede.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN AND MARTIN, (PROCESS)
dialogues.text: Martin strides across to where Ethan is firing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan, quit it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firing again) Nine... (another shot) Ten!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the sense in it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan turns and swings a backhand blow which catches Mart by surprise and fells him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a fury) Hunger! -- Empty bellies! That's the  sense in it, you Cherokee!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swings up his gun and fires again -- and again... as M stares at him from the ground.

dialogues.speaker: THE STAMPEDE, (COLO. FOOTAGE)
dialogues.text: Fear-maddened animals are swinging into full stampede fle the deadly marksman. Rifle shots keep cracking out.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN AND MARTIN AS BEFORE
dialogues.text: The thunder of the hooves is receding and Ethan grimly lo his rifle. Martin picks himself up -- still staring at Et as though at a madman. Ethan turns and looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Least, THEY won't feed any Comanches  this winter... Killin' buffalo's as  good as killin' Injuns in this  country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peaceful tribes depend on the buffalo,  too....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't that too bad... If you feel  that sorry for your kinfolk, I'm  surprised you didn't take up with  that squaw wife of yours...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whips out his shinning knife and strides toward the de buffalo o.s. Martin looks after him with troubled express Suddenly he hears something, borne faint by the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ETHAN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan turns. Now faintly, little more than a shred of sou is the distant blowing of a bugle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen!... Hear it?... There! Ain't  that a bugle... and firing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan stares -- and then the bugle sound repeats and the  distant crack of shots, from long miles off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) Just hope we ain't too late...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the two break and run for their horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as narrator) It was all over long before we got  there and the soldiers was high- tailin' it back to the agency with  their prisoners -- squaws mostly --  by the time Ethan and me reached the  camp...

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN AND MARTIN
dialogues.text: Horses and riders plunge downslope through breast-high sn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the Nawyecky Comanches all  right -- the ones we'd been looking  for all this time...

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: as they ride in, passing dead horses, a few bodies of men

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trouble of it was that the soldiers  had hit when most of the fightin'  men was away -- huntin' maybe... So  most of the dead was old men and  women an' kids... And it was in one  of the tepees Ethan found her -- the  little squaw who wanted me to call  her Look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan has dismounted in front of one of the tepees, heads inside.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: as Ethan enters. A body -- Look's -- is sprawled on the  ground. He crosses, turns her over. Martin enters behind  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're a widower now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) What'd the soldiers have to kill her  for!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees something clutched in her hand. He stoops quickly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan, who has turned indifferently to leave, pauses. Martin shows him what Look had been clutching -- Debbie's rag doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! It's hers, Debbie's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan snatches it, stares at it. Then he turns and runs f the tepee. Martin stares at Look's body, then covers it w a robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we knew Debbie had been in the  village... What Look was doing there --  whether she'd come to warn them, or  maybe to find Debbie for me... there's  no way of knowing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and then slowly heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan stands there, his expression bleak, looking at the  scene. Martin joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta catch up with them yellow  legs... Maybe they got her with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan isn't thinking of that at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) And maybe they got Scar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start away -- fast.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A long line stretching across the landscape -- women fall and being prodded along by their captors. From behind CAM ride Ethan and Martin and move to intercept the column.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: as Ethan and Martin come closer and look at the shawled  prisoners stumbling along.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN AND MARTIN
dialogues.text: as a young OFFICER spurs out of the column and rides towa them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inquiringly) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking for a girl -- a white  girl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'd be about thirteen now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got two around that age...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to wait until we reach  the agency... Fall in behind the  column...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protestingly) But couldn't you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry... (shouting it) Keep the column moving!... Close  ranks there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer spurs out to rejoin the column. Martin looks Ethan, his face alive with hope. But Ethan is just lookin stonily along the line of passing prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The column of cavalry and prisoners enters the agency  (COLORADO FOOTAGE). We see the dead and wounded on travoi the agency Indians watching stoically; the prisoners -- s of them -- being herded into a chapel.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The office has been set up as a temporary army headquarte The GENERAL is being interviewed by two Eastern newspaper CORRESPONDENTS. At a table beyond is a telegrapher, sendi out a report of the victory. A pot-bellied stove supplies heat and the General is warm his hands at it, intermittently. An adjutant is rather we filling out a long official form. The General, for all his mudded boots remains a beau sabr and is loosely modeled upon a certain other well-known gl hunter of the Indian wars. He wears a colonel's straps, b insists upon his brevet rank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it was clear to me the hostiles  outnumbered us four to one... with  all the advantage of terrain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four to one! What did you do, general?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan and Martin enter, stand in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressively) Sir -- we charged!... Gentlemen --  and I hope you will quote me -- I  cannot say too much for the courage  of the men who followed me into that  Cheyenne camp...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blurting it) Cheyenne! What Cheyenne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning and staring) I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That camp you hit was Nawyecka  Comanche... Chief Scar's bunch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fascinated) Scar? What a wonderful name!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his aide) Are you getting this, Keefer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ethan) How do you spell that word --  Nawyecka?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan ignores him, still facing the General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Edwards... I'm looking for  my niece... she was in that camp  when you attacked...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncertain) Well... I know there were some  captives recovered...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Four of 'em dead... so we were told...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably) Unfortunately, the hostiles murdered  them as we developed the village...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure they didn't die of  carbine shots fired by a bunch o'  Yank bluebellies so scared they  couldn't tell the difference between  a Cheyenne and a Comanche?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keefer!... Put this man under arrest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll be the day... (scornfully) 'As we developed the village'...  Next time you develop a village, hit  it where the fightin' men are...   You won't get any headlines for  killin' squaws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keefer coughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I show him the captives, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get him out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir... (he crosses to Ethan) This way...

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: The door is opened by a guard and Ethan takes a step into the room -- then stops in manifest shock. Martin is at his heels, eager and expectant. Beyond them stands  Keefer, grave and compassionate. There is a keening sound the room -- almost an animal sound.

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: It is a simple log-sided room with plank benches without  backs. Up front is a small box-like pulpit, no altar. Across the front of the room, set up either on benches or boards over saw-horses are four blanket-covered figures - at least two being the bodies of children. Squatting on the floor near them is an elderly white woma with hair hanging loosely down her back and clad in India robes. Standing, facing the newcomers, is a woman who may no more than in her mid-thirties. She is mad -- wild-eyed, frightened, with matted, unbrush golden hair, torn garments. It is she who has been making the keening sound, the animal moans. Now she crouches at sight of them and looks desperately for a means of escape Two girls are asleep, heads together and backs to the doo One has light hair, like Debbie's; the other brown hair. afternoon sun coming through a high window touches the li hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie?... DEBBIE?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has seen the light hair and starts crossing the room. Now the madwoman begins her screaming, running from side side like a trapped animal. Ethan follows Martin into the room, Keefer behind him. Martin comes to a stop, realizin the woman is afraid of him. The two sleeping girls stir, do not turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be scared, ma'am...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The madwoman crouches behind one of the benches, looking them with frightened eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't pay any attention to her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin swallows and nods and crosses to the light-haired  girl. He reaches a hand gingerly to touch her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Debbie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the touch, the girl is on her feet, crouching -- one h like a claw, drawn back to rake his face. She is unmistak a white girl, but she is painted like a Comanche woman -- ears red inside, streaks of paint accenting the savagery her face. Her eyes are frightened, yet full of hate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pabo-taibo! (White man!) The other girl has risen almost in  the same instant -- but more out of  fear. She is younger, but painted  like the other. She moves to stand  behind the savage one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) No... She's not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't sure... Where's that doll?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin stares at him, then realizes what he has in mind. He fishes the rag doll from under his coat and holds it o to the girl. She looks at it... and we may almost suspect is rekindling a memory -- but then she spits at it. The o girl laughs. Martin turns away and he's sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was your niece about their age?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not far from it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to realize they're white, isn't  it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) They're not white any more -- they're  Comanche!... Let's see the bodies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin nerves himself for the ordeal, turns to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan and Keefer move away. As they do, the madwoman -- e fixed on the rag doll in Martin's hand -- begins creeping behind him. Martin is torturedly watching Ethan and Keefe as first one blanket then another is raised -- we will ne see the dead. During this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the dispassionate  pro) I'd like you to see them all... It  might help us identify them... Shot  in the head -- flash-burn range...  The boy got his skull cracked...  Here's the girl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin stiffens, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin relaxes... and in that instant the madwoman has th doll in her hands. She cradles it and she croons. Martin reaches to take it away. But she calmly sits, crad the doll, and rocks to and fro, humming a lullaby. He can take it. Ethan returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we only got the one lead -- Scar... And where we begin to look,  I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one thing. We recovered a  bushel of trinkets in that camp...  cheap stuff... trade goods... Couldn't  help noticing that most of it was  Mexican... Maybe if you could talk  to some of those Mexican traders  along the border... What do they  call themselves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comancheros...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the breed... Course it might  take time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time's running out... But I'm obliged  to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They leave.

dialogues.speaker: EVENING
dialogues.text: Laurie has reached the last page of the letter, reading i by the lamp on the table. Jorgensen is knocking out the d ashes of his pipe.  Charlie is in the shadows, a guitar i his hands -- not playing it, but occasionally softly pick a note or chord. Mrs. Jorgensen is dabbing moist eyes wit corner of her apron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so we're setting out for New Mexico  Territory in the morning... I am  sorry I won't be back for Christmas  again this year...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She swallows hard, pauses a moment in her reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quick sympathy) And you knittin' that muffler...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) What's the difference!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I just thought it would be a  sin and a shame not to let SOMEONE  get some good of it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks almost too obviously at Charlie, which annoys  Laurie. Laurie resumes her letter reading:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (peering closely) There's a word crossed out... It  looks like 'I wish' or 'I will'... (she gives up) Anyway... 'I set pen aside in the  hope you are enjoying good health  and your folks the same... I remain,  respectfully... (forlornly) yours truly, Martin Paulie.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all there is. Not a cross on it. Laurie just looks it. Jorgensen stands, pocketing his pipe, easing the cric in his back. He ceremoniously removes the spectacles and  replaces them on the mantel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They never find that girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half to herself) Yours truly... (hotly) And he even has to write his full  name... Martin Pauley... not even  just Martie!... (she stands) I don't care if he never comes back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads for the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising -- saying it  without conviction) Now, Laurie!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie hits the guitar a little stronger. Mrs. Jorgensen looks at him -- and the matchmaker is at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, you'll stay for supper?...   Now I won't take no for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought of saying 'no' never crossed  my mind, Miz Jorgensen... No place  I'd rather be than right here, right  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jorgensen smiles and moves about her duties. Laurie opened the door and is staring out wistfully... and Charl begins playing and singing a verse from "Skip to My Lou."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) One old boot and a button shoe One  old boot and a button shoe...

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The search theme is heard again as the two riders, with s pack horse, are heading south through New Mexico. It is hot country.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Their faces are sun-tanned, burned dark and dry. Gone are the heavy coats and clothing of their northern days. They not speak, just ride -- and there is the same bleak, fana hard look about them both. The music theme segues into  something livelier and Mexican as we -

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN AND MARTIN
dialogues.text: It is a small place -- a single dirt street, a few adobe  houses; a few racks of dried meat; a burro with a load of faggots on its back being driven along by a small boy; th music coming from a little cantina in the middle of the  street. Before the cantina is a bone rack of a horse, wit a saddle -- only a blanket pad. There is something famili about the horse and Ethan is staring at it as they ride i

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The two men dismount, beating dust out of their clothes. Ethan takes another look at the sorry old nag tied outsid Martin pauses beside Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recognize it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin shakes his head. They start toward the cantina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There couldn't be two like that in  all the world...

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: as Ethan and Martin enter. It is a dirt-floored room with small bar near the door, chairs and benches along the wal A pair of guitar players are at the far end of the room. couple of Mexicans are playing a noisy game of dominoes,  slapping the dominoes down hard... EMILIO FIGUEROA, back the door, spurred boots across one of the tables, is sipp a drink. Emilio is a cynical, middle-aged, aristocratic- looking man in modified charro costume. Watching the domi game is ESTRELLA, lithe, sensuous, smoking a brown-paper  cigarette; she is barefoot. Behind the bar is the proprie dozing on his stool. Ethan takes a step into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly) MOSE!.... MOSE HARPER?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The proprietor awakens. The domino game is suspended in m play. Estrella turns... and from beside Emilio, previousl obscured by the man's back and the big charro hat, pokes head of old Mose. Emilio turns then to look at the newcom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay-eh...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is on his feet and advancing to meet them. As he recog them a wide, foolish grin splits his face and his mouth o and closes in words that won't come out. He grabs and sha Ethan's arm, then Martin's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leggo my arm... You look mangier 'n  ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't been too good... No sir, not  too good... Gettin' old, Ethan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were born old...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all smiles - as they  head for the bar) Bienvenidos, senores... Pulque?...   tequila?... mescal?... huiskey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tequila...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lo mismo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming) Y' par' el Viejo -- el vino del  pais... tequila tambien!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin puts his back to the bar, leans elbows on it and l around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is giving him an appraising once-over, then signals t musicians to play. She rests her buttocks against a table and waits, her eyes challenging Martin to make a move. Em is watching Estrella and Martin with something akin to bo amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan has poured a drink for Mose, now one for himself -- leaving Martin's glass empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been helpin' ye, Ethan... I been  lookin' all the time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin turns back to the bar to take his glass. He finds empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ethan's back) Thanks for nothin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He angrily throws a coin on the counter, appropriates the bottle and his glass and heads for a table closer to Estr Neither Ethan nor Mose seems aware of his going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the reward still stands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't want no money, Ethan... jus' a  place -- a roof over m' head... a  little grub... a bunk to sleep in...  an' a rockin' chair by the fire...   my own rockin' chair by a fire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You help me find her, you got your  rockin' chair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swear it, Ethan?... Given word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Told ya, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressively) Ethan... I found a man's seen her...   knows where little Debbie is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan stares at him. Mose nods his reaffirmation of it. Then Ethan's hand locks on the old man's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Where is he... this man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mose winces under the grip. He can't speak, but he looks  past Ethan and he points. Ethan turns. Emilio swings his  boots off the table and slowly crosses to them. He lets  cigarette smoke curl out of his mouth. Then he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am this man, senor... Emilio Gabriel  Fernandez y Figueroa... at your  service... (afterthought) ...for a price... (he smiles) ...Always for a price...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the men study each other, Estrella begins her dance -- and the rhythmic click of the castanets will beat like a  metronome. Emilio looks at the bottle on the bar, disdain pushes it away and imperiously signals the proprietor to  bring something better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Un otra!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is knocking off his tequila and looking at the girl  hungrily. She is doing her swaying dance, playing up to h and with unmistakable effect. He sloshes another drink in his glass and, never taking his eyes off her, downs it.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER ANGLE
dialogues.text: Beyond Estrella we see Ethan, Emilio, and Mose at the bar gestures, headshakes, the entire pantomime of an inaudibl conversation. Then Ethan takes out his pouch and begins  dropping gold pieces into Emilio's hand. Meanwhile, dance and dancer are achieving their purpose with Martin. And t tequila is working. He gets to his feet, a little groggil Estrella's smile deepens and there is a clear invitation her eyes... Ethan turns then, his deal with Emilio conclu and he sees what is going on. He starts for Martin's tabl just as Martin moves out to take the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tolerantly) Come on, Don Juan... We're on our  way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin tries to push him away, his eyes still on the girl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thickly) Lemme alone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his arm) You breeds are all alike -- two drinks  an'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin breaks free and squares off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take yer hands off'n me... This lady  an' me got some things to talk over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Estrella ranges herself alongside of Martin and slips an possessively through his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a shrug) Suit yourself... While you're enjoyin'  your little conversation, I'll be  ridin' out with Senor Fernandez  here...  The Comanch' medicine country  ain't far... there's one camp with a  chief named Cicatriz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cicatriz is Mex for Scar... an' he  has a white girl in his tepee... Be  seein' you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and heads out. Emilio, who has come up behind hi gives Estrella a slight smile and bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
