dialogues.text: Buena suerte, Estrella... Hasta la  vista.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He follows Ethan. Estrella swings her body close to Marti and lets her arms slide around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Tu quieres...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin blinks to clear away the fog of tequila and desire

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bitter laugh) Sure... sure... Only not this year...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her arms away and goes lurching after the others Mose catches his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Mind Ethan 'bout my rockin' chair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin continues out and Mose stands there -- his head ro as though he already were in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A small pack train (nine or ten horses, six or seven men) winds through a canyon behind which we can see huge needl of rock: majestic, savage country. At the head of the col ride Ethan, Emilio, and Martin. Behind them come Emilio's cargadores -- lean, hard-bitten wiry little Mexicans. One leads a handsome palomino. The SOUND of the CASTANETS ECH in the musical theme.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD OF COLUMN
dialogues.text: Ethan is looking around with grim interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medicine country, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slight smile) Medicine so strong they believe the  feather of an eagle found here can  guard a man against bullets...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking ahead) If you got one handy, now's the  time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan and Emilio both look in the direction of his glance

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: They are turning a bend and now, ahead, we see a cordon o Comanches -- all armed, all quiet, all very menacing as t watch the approaching column. Emilio calls a greeting in  Comanche. It gets no answer.

dialogues.speaker: THE COMANCHE FACES
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PICKS UP the faces in turn, as from the white  men's viewpoint, as they ride slowly by.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: One tepee stands apart from the other's -- Scar's. Beyond are other tepees, the gathering of braves and some squaws the drying racks for meat, etc. Emilio leads the way towa the central tepee. They dismount nearby and Emilio inclin his head toward the one tepee. Ethan and Martin brace  themselves and wait. The flap of the tepee is closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gruffly) What are we waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilio cautions him with a hand gesture.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The flap is thrust aside and SCAR steps out -- the same  Comanche we had seen at the grave when Debbie was capture He stands tall, arrogant, eyeing the white men with hard, implacable eyes. He has a robe gathered about him. Across his face is a scar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senores! This is Cicatriz!

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN AND MARTIN -
dialogues.text: The white men's eyes are as hard as the Comanche's: this the man they have long sought, the killer, the raper. They cannot mask the hatred they feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly... at last) Scar... It's plain to see where you  got your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scar's hand moves to the scar on his face, and a finger r along it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name - Big Shoulders... His  name - He Who Follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You speak pretty good American for a  Comanche... Someone teach you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a leading question and Scar knows it. He looks long Ethan and the suggestion of a smile touches his lips. But he makes no direct answer. He looks instead to Emilio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Comanche) Ah-we pabbo-tie-bo ee-kee-tay? (Why did you bring  the gringos here?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a shrug -- in Comanche) Pabbo-tie-bo kim te-moo-er. (The gringos want to  trade.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right... We come to trade...  Only not out here... (with sign language  accompaniment) I don't stand talkin' in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilio quickly turns and calls to one of his men. Emilio worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Miguel... caballo -- aca!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the Mexicans comes on the trot, leading in the  palomino. Emilio makes a gesture -- giving it to Scar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Co-bay tabitz-chat. (meaning) (Very fine horse.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scar looks at it greedily, then nods. He'll accept it. He looks at Ethan. Again that faintly contemptuous smile. He signals them to enter his tepee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Martin) Stay out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not likely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He follows Ethan into the tepee... and a worried Emilio g along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small fire burns in the center of the lodge and a shaft sunlight strikes in from the smoke flap at the peak. Two chunky squaws, who have been tending the fire or grin corn in a rock pestle, scuttle to a side of the tepee. Tw others, one half-grown and the other slightly taller, sit with their backs to the fire, huddled over some leather w or stitching. Both are shawled. As Scar enters, he barks word to the squaws near the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pie-kay! (Clear out!) (then he turns to the  white men) IH-CARD! (Sit!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits on some robes, signs for them to sit opposite. Slowly they look around them.

dialogues.speaker: TTE TWO OLDER SQUAWS
dialogues.text: They are sitting with heads averted, slightly profiled -- but clearly Indian women, broad-faced, dark of hair and s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His sons are dead... So his wives  sit on the honor side of his lodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at them) Are those his wives too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the squaws turns -- and even in the shadows we see is another Indian face. The other does not turn. Scar leans in, blocking the view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two sons -- killed by white men...  For each son, I take many scalps... (in Comanche) Mayah-kay zee-eh!... (Bring the lance!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slightly smaller of the young squaws stiffens but doe move. Scar glares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder) MAYAH-KAY ZEE-EH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl gets to her feet. Ethan and Martin watch as, sti with averted face, she crosses to where a lance hangs fro the tepee wall. It has several scalps on it, including on with light red hair. Slowly she carries it back. Scar nev takes his eyes from the faces of the white men, savoring  every moment of it. The girl extends the lance between th so that it is like a bare blade separating two duelists.  Neither Ethan nor Martin dares at first look at more than the scalp pole... Then slowly their eyes lift... and the  CAMERA MOVES IN and RAISES TO:

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: As the shawl slips back to reveal her light hair, the sla green eyes looking at them from a tanned, but still white and very beautiful face. (NOTE TO MUSIC: The SEARCH THEME should cover all the foregoing action -- but at the first clear view of DEBBIE, it ends dramatically.) Debbie's eyes hold theirs -- and then Scar's voice is hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Comanche) Pie-kay! (Go!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swiftly she straightens, takes away the scalp pole and go back to her former place.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP AS BEFORE
dialogues.text: Scar is watching the white men like a hawk. Martin's eyes are wide and his breathing seems suspended. But Ethan is  playing it like a poker player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his voice controlled) I've seen scalps before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scar's eyes are mocking. He lets his robe slip back from shoulders, revealing a bare bronzed chest on which -- gli in the reflected firelight -- is the medallion that Ethan had given Debbie. It is suspended by a chain or rawhide  string. Scar touches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan smiles -- and he's still playing poker. He stands.. and the others follow. Scar is puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Emilio) I came to trade, not to admire his  collection... Tell him we're going  to pitch camp across the crick...  Maybe we can talk trade tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scar hasn't understood all of it. He scowls and looks at  Emilio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Comanche) Ee-sap! Pabbo-tie-bo ee-sap! (He lies! The gringo  lies!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (placatingly) Tomorrow -- manana -- 'puetze.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scar looks at Ethan and at Martin. He smiles slightly, an he nods his agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puetze!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin and Ethan turn to go. Only then does Debbie look  swiftly at them and as swiftly away. Martin can't help bu pause, but Ethan prods him toward the tepee flap.

dialogues.speaker: MOVING
dialogues.text: They emerge from the tepee and begin to walk away -- not  fast, not slow, and without a side glance. Scar emerges a looks after them -- glowering. A few other Comanches begi to gather near his tepee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgently) Walk with dignity! (after a moment; lips  hardly moving) If you gringo heretics have any  prayers, say them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (transfigured) She's alive... Can you believe it,  she's alive... alive... An' we found  her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fervently) Please!... I, too, am alive... I  wish to stay that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the waiting cargadores and the pack train,  surrounded by suspicious Comanches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his men) Vamanos!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They mount and ride out.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Emilio is standing near his horse, talking to Ethan and  Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand, senores... It is not  that I am cobarde... cowardly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't apologize... You did your job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilio nods and mounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows you -- who you are -- and  why you are here... This I did not  understand... or I would not... even  for gold, senores... have led you  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fumbles for a pouch, holds it out to Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it. I do not want blood money.  Vaya con Dios!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He digs spurs and rides out. Ethan turns and looks soberl at Martin. We hear the rest of the riders moving away. Ethan and Martin cross the sand and go down slope toward creek where their horses are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You figger Scar means to kill us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got to... All these years,  runnin', dodgin', knowin' we were  after him... Now we caught up...  It's him or us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't he make his move back  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... Somethin' tied his  hands... maybe hospitality...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks and both wheel as sand slides from the top of t dunes. They look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie is silhouetted atop the dune, looking down at them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely breathing the  name) Debbie...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slides down the dune to stand across the creek from t

dialogues.speaker: THE THREE
dialogues.text: Her hand cautions them to silence and against coming any  closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Comanche) Unnt-meah! (Go away!) Both men move closer. She takes a  frightened step back, as if to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie... Don't you remember me? I'm  Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates. She looks long at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Comanche) Unnt-meah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) We ain't goin'! We ain't goin' without  you, Debbie... Ethan, get the  horses... I'll try to keep her  talkin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) How? She's even forgot her own  language!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie, you're comin' with us!  Hear  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... not now... not ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These have been her first words in English... and they br new hope to Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what they've done to  you... what happened...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) They have done... nothing... They  are my people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your people? They murdered your  family!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reverting to Comanche) Ee-sap! (furiously) White men killed them - to steal  cows! I was... little... I ran away...  They find me... take care of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Debbie! That ain't what happened!   They been lyin' to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lie! All white men lie... and  kill...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie, think back! I'm Martin...   remember? Remember how I used to let  you ride my horse? Tell you stories?   Don't you remember me, Debbie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember... from always... At first  I prayed to you... come and get me...  take me home... You didn't come...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've come now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are my people... (in Comanche) Unnt-meah! Go! Go! Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) Stand aside, boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin turns as Ethan slowly reaches for his gun. It take Martin a moment to realize what he is about to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan -- NO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves quickly then to put himself between Ethan and th girl and in that instant there is the crack of a rifle. Ethan is hit in the leg. It goes out from under him. Mart swings and his gun is out and firing.

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING THE DUNES
dialogues.text: A mounted Comanche is on the crest of the dune above them rifle raised. Martin's first shot brings him down the dun in a spectacular horse-and-man fall. Debbie goes running  like a deer up the creek, away from Martin; in the same  instant we hear the angry yells of distant Comanches char from the far left. Martin turns to see Debbie running awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie! WAIT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan is on his feet now and limping frantically toward t horses. He shoves Martin ahead of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Never mind her! MOVE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They mount and take off, just as the vanguard of the atta Comanches swings around a point of rock and comes chargin toward the creek.

dialogues.speaker: LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: as Ethan and Martin race their horses from the creek area and down a long incline, as -- from the heights above -- dozen or more Comanches, led by Scar, come tearing after  them.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Ethan is swaying in his saddle, just barely hanging on, a Martin races up behind him -- driving Ethan's horse along They swing past a huge outcrop of rock and go tearing alo a vaulting wall of stone. Their hoofbeats and those of th pursuers bounce and echo off the canyon walls, and bullet whine and ricochet.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: They swing around giant boulders, up-ended like pancakes. Ethan is lurching almost out of the saddle, barely consci Martin spots the cave -- ahead -- and drives his mount an Ethan's toward it.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO
dialogues.text: Martin pulls his horse in and swings off just as Ethan sl from his saddle. He runs toward one of the huge boulders, crouches and starts firing.

dialogues.speaker: THE COMANCHES
dialogues.text: The Comanches are spread out but coming on fast. One goes down under Martin's fire.... another is hit in the arm. H pulls up and the other Comanches wheel away from the hidd marksman.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN AND ETHAN
dialogues.text: Martin runs back from his firing post toward where Ethan fallen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Go on! Get out of here while you  can...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the cave) Over there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan turns and sees what he means. He starts dragging hi to the cave as Martin grabs the rifles from their saddle  scabbards, yanks off the water canteens and then drives t horses away. Then he too runs for the shelter of the cave

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both men are crouching, rifles ready. In the distance we their horses running off -- pursued by some yelling Coman Four or six others come into sight, heading for the cave moving cautiously, uncertainly -- not seeing their quarry Then the white men open fire and the Comanches bend low o their horses' necks and clear out of there. Ethan looks g at Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll be back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't be here... Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets an arm under Ethan and hauls him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: SUNSET
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS from the top of the rock chimney to where Mar is snaking his way through, carrying newly-filled water  canteens. He stands there, listening and looking back the way he has come; and then, satisfied there has been no  pursuit, he continues away.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Ethan is lying on the hard earth, perhaps cushioned with  some boughs. He is half delirious. A small fire is burnin Martin enters carrying the canteens. He looks  unsympathetically toward Ethan, then continues to the fir takes a knife and starts to sterilize it. Ethan gasps, mu and then a word comes clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha... Martha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin stares at him -- and now, perhaps for the first ti he is fitting pieces into the jig-saw puzzle. He shifts c to Ethan and we see he is preparing to dig out the bullet Ethan opens his eyes and looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta open that leg and let the  poison out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He poises the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fumbles in his shirt pocket, brings out a greasy folde piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just in case... Read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin sets the knife down, takes the paper, opens it and slowly reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'I, Ethan Edwards, being of sound  mind and without any blood kin, do  hereby bequeath all my property of  any kind to Martin Pauley...' (he stares, then) I don't want your property.... 'Sides,  what do you mean no 'blood kin?'  Debbie's your blood kin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) You can keep your will! (he thrusts it back  into Ethan's shirt) I ain't forgettin' you was all set  to shoot her yourself... What kind  o' man are you, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting up -- eyes  blazing) She's been with the bucks! She's  nothin' now but a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin shoves him back onto the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a shout) Shut your dirty mouth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets to his feet, trembling, and stands looking down a Ethan, his fists clenched at his sides and murder in his  eyes. Then his eyes rove to the knife lying on the blanke He picks it up and he looks again at the wounded man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) I hope you die!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he kneels again to open the wound.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN AND MARTIN
dialogues.text: Martin is hauling an improvised travois over the ground i which, lashed by vines and some clothing, is the unconsci figure of Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: MOVING
dialogues.text: Eyes shadowed, whiskered, drawn -- he is an implacable fi as he drags the weary miles home. He hears a groan from E o.s. He barely lets his eyes drift to the sound. He doesn stop.

dialogues.speaker: MOVING
dialogues.text: We see he is delirious, lips parched, strapped to the pol The travois jolts over the ground. As he passes out of fr the CAMERA HOLDS on the marks of the travois poles scrapi across the desert.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: A party is in progress. Fiddler and banjo-player are play a lively square dance for one or two sets of dancers --  ranchers, their wives and daughters. Laurie is not in  evidence. At the far end of the room is a table with a pu bowl set up and a cluster of men and women about. Jorgensen is at the door boisterously welcoming some new  arrivals. Leading them into the room is Captain the Rever Sam Clayton, with a bulky oil-skin package under his arm. With him is Charlie MacCorry, dressed in his best black s and scrubbed until he looks raw. Behind them come three or four other competent-looking me Rangers all of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) They're here, mama... Come in, come  in...

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING GROUP AT DOOR
dialogues.text: Clayton waits for Charlie to come abreast, then hits him the back and drives him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here he is, Lars... Combed, curried  'n washed behind the ears!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jorgensen hurries over, beaming, to admire Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Charlie, you look real handsome!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Yes'm... scarcely reck'nize myself...  Where's Laurie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jorgensen smiles and playfully pushes him toward the guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see her soon enough...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton -- and the other Rangers -- have been hanging gun on pegs along the wall. Now he shakes out his parcel --  disclosing a green-black frock coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding to the music) Say, that music sounds so good it  must be sinful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grab a partner, reverend!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now, a man of my age just can't  haul off and dance in cold blood...  but if there's any of that wild cherry  brandy of yours, Lars...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly sober) Nooo... (change of heart) Yah, by golly... One jug left... I  get it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jorgensen glares as he heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last winter that man swore up and  down there wasn't a drop left -- and  me with pneumoney!... Reverend, you'd  better start clergyin' again!

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Horses, wagons fill the yard. We can hear the lively musi of the square dance. As Jorgensen opens the door and sets out toward the barn, a battered dusty trap drives in -- a on it are Martin and Ethan. Jorgensen at first doesn't  recognize them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hailing them) Hi!... You're late... hurry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then he sees who they are, and his jaw drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring) Ethan... Martie... No, don't get  down! ...You can't come in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rangers are here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says it as though that explains everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that got to do with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyeing the house) What's goin' on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who's forgotten they  wouldn't know) Why, my Laurie's getting married...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin throws the reins aside and jumps out. Jorgensen gr his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! Don't you hear me! The  Rangers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been posted for murder... both  of you... That trader fella, the  late Mister Futterman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin tries to break free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta see Laurie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately) Go around the side... the  grandmother's room... I'll tell her...  PLEASE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads around the side. Ethan meanwhile has climbed sti down, slightly favoring his leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick... hide in the barn, Ethan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hide? Why would I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brushes past the little man and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he enters, with Jorgensen at his heels. For a moment, he stands there, the party breezes on. Then first one, th another sees him. They gape, and the music falters and st Sam Clayton crosses to confront him across the width of t room. Jorgensen tries to be the easy, smiling host--and m a very bad job of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look everybody... Look who's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't even finish it but stands there making flapping  gestures.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN AND SAM
dialogues.text: -- others gaping. During the opening lines, Jorgensen wil covertly back toward the door to the inner room -- Laurie room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to all) Evenin'... evenin' Reverend... or do  I call you 'Captain'...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Came here for a wedding, Ethan...  Until that's over, I reckon 'reverend'  will do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming forward) And news of our little girl, Ethan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face contorts and his smile is twisted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not a little girl any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes wide) You've seen her!... She's alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen her... and she's alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jorgensen throws herself against his chest, sobbing. Ethan looks past her at Clayton. And the faces of both me are grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dark. Martin is pacing, eyes constantly turni to the inside door. And then it opens and Laurie is insid holding a lamp. She is in her bridal gown and very obviou trying to keep from betraying the stress she is under.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Hello, Martie....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just stares at her -- very lovely, strangely remote. He suddenly is conscious of his dirty hands, his dusty, w clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I wrote you a letter... Reckon  you didn't get it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (setting the lamp  down) One letter in five years... I read  it till the paper dried up and the  writing faded out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't much of a letter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it wasn't... You mighta said you  loved me... You mighta asked me to  wait... At least that'd have been  something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I allus loved you... You know  that, without my sayin' it... I  couldn't bring myself to ask you to  wait... the little I had... not  knowin' how much longer until we  found Debbie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaking) It isn't fair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sinks onto the bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing) It isn't fair, Martin Pauley, and  you know it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins to cry, very softly. He is beside her and his goes around her shoulder comfortingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't cry, Laurie... I understand  how it is... I'll just go 'way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spinning on him) You do and I'll die, Martie... I  will! I'll just die!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they are kissing through her tears when the outer doo is flung open by Charlie MacCorry. They part as he glares

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll thank you to leave the room,  Laurie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin stares at him, then at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Charlie MacCorry!... You weren't  fixin' to marry HIM??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sure is!... An' don't think your  comin' back is goin' to change it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As to that, I don't know, Charlie...  We hadn't got around to talkin'  marriage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What right you got to be talkin'  marriage to any decent woman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) If you're talkin' about that crazy  murder charge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AND other things... Mebbe you thought  you was gettin' away with being  comical about that Indian wife you  took... I bet she wasn't the first  squaw you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin swings wildly but Charlie is a wily fighter. He si steps and chops Martin in the jaw and drives him against wall. Laurie runs between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! Both of you... I won't have  any fighting in this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin gently brushes her aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right... Charlie, let's  move outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't wearing no gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin nods and unbuckles his gunbelt. The men head outsi as Laurie runs to get help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie waits assuredly as Martin follows him outside. Martin makes a wild run, swings. The blow is neatly guard by Charlie's left and countered with a crisp right that p Martin down. Martin gets to his feet, more cautiously thi time, and comes in at a crouch; he's fighting like an Ind not a white man. The men from the wedding party come out at a run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Sergeant MacCorry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie turns slightly and in that instant Martin springs and drives a straight right at his face -- almost as thou there were a knife in the hand. MacCorry stumbles back in Clayton's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this in the line of duty, sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regaining his balance) No sir... pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case, give the boys room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin waits at a crouch as Charlie comes in, feints his  right and crosses his left. It is a hard blow but Martin  recovers and waits... Charlie circles and starts to repea He feints his right but this time Martin springs in, duck and -- as the left shoots out -- he grabs the wrist and t Charlie over his head. What we are looking at, in effect, a wrestler against a boxer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fight fair, son... Use your fists!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) Comanches don't use their fists,  reverend... Let 'em alone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is on his feet and warily starts circling -- now  trying to imitate Martin's crouch. Suddenly Martin feints right swing and connects with a solid left -- reversing t order of business. Charlie staggers and Martin follows up with a wrestling hold, leaping behind Charlie, locking bo legs around him and driving his arms upward behind his ba so that his face is in the dirt and so he could -- under  other circumstances -- be neatly and expeditiously scalpe With the hands locked, Martin then calmly draws a knife. looks innocently into the aghast faces of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could scalp him... but I'll just  count coup!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that he releases the paralyzed arms just long enough grab a lock of Charlie's hair and neatly snip it off. He stands then and laughs as Charlie lamely gets to his f easing the tortured arms. Clayton goes to Charlie's side. Laurie moves to Martin's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right, sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunno... Seems so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, go get cleaned up and we'll  proceed with the weddin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie frowns and looks off at where Laurie and Martin a standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't goin' to be any weddin' -- not  till we get a few things cleared up  'round here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks rather unsteadily away leaving a thunderstruck  assembly, murmurous with surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last of the wedding guests is leaving: Ed Nesby carry his bull fiddle and with his wife and daughter and two sm children preceding him out the door. The Jorgensens stand by -- trying to put a good face on t wedding debacle. Charlie MacCorry is sitting dejectedly,  studying a spot on the floor. Ethan is at the mantel. Lau is in her room -- presumably changing out of her wedding  gown. Martin is at a sink, bathing a cut on his lip. Clay still in his clerical coat, is near the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a grin) Well... it was a nice weddin' party...   considerin' no one got married...  'Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Ed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jorgensen puts her handkerchief to her eyes -- letti down now that the guests have gone. Jorgensen crosses to  her, pats her sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, mamma!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads her away. Clayton faces Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to ask you and Martin to ride  to the State Capitol with me, Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This an invite to a necktie party,  Reverend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain... Nope, wouldn't say that...  Likely you had your reasons for  killin' Futterman... Probably needed  killin'... I'm speaking as a ranger  now, not as a reverend... Fact that  all three was shot in the back is  the only thing that's raised some  question -- that and a missin' gold  piece known to have been on him just  prior to his demise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan casually reaches into his pocket, takes out a gold  coin and spins it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) That so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin crosses to confront Clayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't goin' to Austin, Reverend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie gets to his feet and he has his gun in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're goin' if the captain says  you're goin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now... let's not grow  disputatious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast hoofbeats sound o.s. -- signalling the approach of a four-man cavalry detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning) What's that? More company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Jorgensen head for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinda late getting here, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A voice hails from outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello there! Captain Clayton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton stands in the opened doorway, Jorgensen behind hi looking out. Drawn up outside is the four-man cavalry det led by a young and very crisp LIEUTENANT. We may or may n see the sixth man, slouched over his horse. The Lieutenan swings off and crosses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Captain Clayton here, Reverend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Clayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lieutenant gapes at Clayton's ministerial coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubtfully) You're Captain Clayton?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan chuckles, to Clayton's very obvious annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recovering, he salutes) Colonel Greenhill's compliments,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Colonel wishes to know how soon you could put a compa of Rangers in the field, fully armed and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, son... Who's this Colonel  Greenhill you're talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why Colonel Greenhill is Colonel  Greenhill, sir... Commanding Officer,  Fifth U.S. Cavalry... I'm Lieutenant  Greenhill, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Now what's this your pa wants  to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pa wants to know... Colonel  Greenhill wants to know how soon you  could put a company of your Rangers  in the field, fully armed and  equipped, for joint punitive action  against the Comanches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOINT action?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir... We've received information  about a band of Comanches under a  chief named Scar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What information?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That maybe he's not far from here -- holed up somewhere, waiting his chance  to get back over the border... He  raided north about a month ago...  ran into more army than he bargained  for... Now he's running for cover,  for keeps this time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what makes you think he's in  this territory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday, one of our patrols picked  up a man claims he was a prisoner  with Scar till only two days ago...  He talks crazy but I brought him  along... Says he lives here... keeps  mentioning a rocking chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half to himself) Mose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then he is striding to the door, calling it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOSE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay-he?... Ay-eh?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the old man totters in, half-supported by a trooper - hollow-eyed, weak, almost delirious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come f'r my rockin' chai'... ole  Mose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting it) Where's Scar, Mose... SCAR?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask him about Debbie!... Is she all  right, Mose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My rockin' chai'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bustling over) Leave the poor man be! Can't you see  he's out of his mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to lead him away, but Ethan shoves her aside an grips the old man by his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mose... try to remember!... You were  in Scar's camp...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay-he... Made out I was crazy... (he giggles foolishly) Ate dirt... chewed grass... I fooled  'em, Ethan!... an' I got away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scar! Where's he holed in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven Fingers... ay-he... Seven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He staggers and this time Mrs. Jorgensen won't be denied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's enough!  Here... by the  fire... What you need's a good bowl  of soup...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads him away, at last to his rocker by the fire. During this, Ethan and Clayton have been mulling Mose's  answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blankly) Seven Fingers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what he told us... but there's  no such place on the maps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! Isn't that the Caddo  name for where all those canyons  branch on the Malapai?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from his rocker) Caddo or Kiowa... ay-he... ay-eh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam Clayton wheels on the Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell your pa a company of Rangers --  all fourteen of 'em -- fully armed  an' equipped will be in the field by  daylight... headin' for the south  end of the Malapai. If he can catch  up with us, well an' good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... but captain, we can't possibly  take the field tomorrow... for your  own protection...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny, yonder's a passel of murderers,  complete with Texican scalps an'  white girl captive... You want to  protect us, you just get out of our  way... Now skedaddle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lieutenant skedaddles. Sam whirls on Martin and Ethan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan, you an' Martin are hereby  appointed civilian scouts -- without  pay... Charlie, hightail it to  headquarters an' spread the word...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves. Martin's hands go to his side -- recalling whe he left his guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My guns...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads for the inner door to the grandmother room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Martin enters and crosses to where he had dropped his  gunbelt. Even before he reaches it, Laurie is in the room closing the door after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martie... don't go! Not this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring) You crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too late... She's a woman grown  now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to fetch her home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fetch what home?... The leavin's of  Comanche bucks -- sold time an' again  to the highest bidder?... With savage  brats of her own, most like?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting it) Laurie! Shut your mouth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what Ethan will do if he  has a chance?... He'll put a bullet  in her brain! And I tell you Martha  would want him to!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if I'm dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides out past her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Martin re-enters. Ethan and Sam are waiting. Martin lo hard at Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes never leaving  Ethan's face) I'm ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they stride out,

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: as she stands at the window, in her bridal gown, and sadl watches Martin again going away. Softly the score reprise sadly now -- "Skip to My Lou."

dialogues.speaker: THE RANGERS
dialogues.text: A file of eighteen men and horses -- Rangers -- is walkin under the shoulder of a mesa, keeping well below the skyl

dialogues.speaker: THE FILE OF RANGERS
dialogues.text: They pass CAMERA one by one -- Sam Clayton in the lead, M behind him leading two horses, then the others -- grim- looking, capable men of varying ages; some with long droo mustaches, some in need of shaves, some chawing tobacco.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: He is lying prone, his hat off, squinting down into a lon reach of desert canyon at the Comanche encampment -- with tepees set up, a thin wisp of smoke rising from a fire, t horse herd penned in a draw cut off by an improvised corr of rawhide ropes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camp is sleeping. A dog yaps shrilly. One of the tepe flaps opens and Scar steps out. He picks up a stone or a  chunk of wood and throws it. The dog yelps and runs off.  Scar's air is troubled, suspicious. He heads for the hors herd. The camp sleeps on.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: His face betrays a bitter inner satisfaction. He looks ba along the trail as faintly we hear the approach of the Ra company. Then he squirms back, retrieving his hat.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD OF RANGER COLUMN
dialogues.text: Sam, seeing Ethan in the near distance, raises his hand i signal for halt and waits. Ethan scrambles down the trail join him. He takes the reins of his horse from Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can get within 500 yards... there's  a hogback to the south.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many, would you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) Enough to go around... I'd say about  a dozen apiece... Mount 'em up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves as though to mount, but Martin steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! We go chargin' in, they'll  kill her... and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) It's what I'm countin' on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam stares at him, but Martin isn't surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you are... Only it ain't goin'  to be that way... she's alive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Livin' with Comanches ain't bein'  alive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same tone) She's alive... Better she's alive  and livin' with Comanches than her  brains bashed out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now son, it's a bitter thing to say,  but there's more than your sister at  stake here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There sure is! I'm going to tell you  somethin'... I wasn't going to speak  of it... But I'll tell you now.  Did  you notice them scalps strung on  Scar's lance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see the third scalp from the  point of the lance? Long... wavy  hair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw it... And don't try to tell me  it was Aunt Martha's or Lucy's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't remember it, but I remember.  That was your mother's scalp!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin stares, quick disbelief in his eyes. But Ethan's e hold his and there is no doubting the truth in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to tell you... but  maybe it's your right to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Now mount up, son...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam puts his hand on Martin's elbow -- as though to turn to his duty. But Martin jerks the arm away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It don't change it... All I'm askin'  is a chance to sneak in there... an'  try to get her out before you come  chargin' in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if you're caught?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't tell 'em anything, will it!  Just a man alone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say NO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, son... But at the first  alarm, we're comin' in -- and we  ain't goin' to have time to pick and  choose our targets when we do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan looks long and hard at Martin, then reaches into hi shirt for the folded, dirty, dog-eared paper that was his will. Slowly he tears it into shreds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your funeral...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin squats and starts pulling off his boots. He glance up as Charlie MacCorry comes over, an Indian blanket in h hands. He tosses it onto Martin's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here... you fight like a Comanch...  Maybe this'll help ya pass as one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he grins and extends his hand. Martin takes it -- an they shake as Charlie pulls him to his feet. Martin drops his hat, and then -- at a crouching run -- he heads for t distant Comanche camp.

dialogues.speaker: FROM BEHIND CLAYTON AND ETHAN, TOWARD MARTIN
dialogues.text: as he runs downslope under the shelter of the hogback tow the unseen camp. Clayton waves an arm at his men and star leading out -- in a somewhat different direction.

dialogues.speaker: THE RANGERS, FAVORING CLAYTON AND ETHAN
dialogues.text: They are leading their horses down the slope, still under the lee of the butte, when two riders are seen approachin at a fast gallop -- Lt. Greenhill and his courier. (The l is a bugler).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling -- still  distant) Captain Clayton... Captain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam whips off his hat and makes frantic signals to Greenh to shut up. Greenhill pulls to a canter, puzzled, and rid in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding) Go on! Whyn't you have your bugler  sound the charge while you're at  it??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blankly) Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind... Your pa know you're  out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir... Troop's about ten miles  back... The Colonel sent me looking  for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissing him) Well you found me... Good work, son...  Good work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts away. Greenhill follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's anything I can do, sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) God forbid... No, son, you flog on  back and tell your pa where we're  at... and where he's at...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he knows THAT, sir... Can't I  stay, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) All right... But keep your eye on  me, boy... I'm the hard case you're  up against here -- not these childish  savages... If you don't hear me first  time I holler, you better read my  mind... I don't aim to raise no two  hollers on any subject at hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whips out his sabre -- to the imminent peril of Captai Sam who quickly shifts out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch that knife, boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Sam continues away and the Rangers after him.

dialogues.speaker: DAWN LIGHT
dialogues.text: Martin runs from behind CAMERA and dodges behind a rock. camp is still asleep, very quiet. Martin runs out from be the rock and makes another short dash toward the camp,  dropping behind a pile of blankets or other impedimenta. dog runs out of one of the tepees, begins barking.

dialogues.speaker: SCAR
dialogues.text: He stands with another Comanche -- inspecting the horse l In the near distance the dog's barking is heard -- shrill insistent. Scar, almost like an animal, sniffs the air  suspiciously. The other Comanche laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tahbo. (A rabbit.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scar isn't satisfied but returns to his work.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He is staring at it -- remembering it from certain distin decorations. The lower part of the tepee is rolled up, fo better air circulation. Martin wraps Charlie's blanket ar him and begins walking to the tepee.

dialogues.speaker: RANGERS
dialogues.text: The line is drawn up, dismounted, the men checking their  sidearms, tightening cinches, etc. Sam moves briskly alon the line of men, then mounts his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The State of Texas is payin' you  boys $12 a month. Here's your chance  to earn it... Now I don't want any  foolin' around after scalps. We ain't  got the time... Yankee cavalry's on  its way here to set those Comanches  free... We gotta beat 'em to it --  our way... Now mount an' guide center  on young Greenhill here. Son, you  just follow me... And WATCH THAT  KNIFE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last comes as Greenhill tries to mount, simultaneousl flailing out his sabre perilously close to Clayton.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Martin has gained the tepee, takes one quick look around, then strides in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Martin enters. One robe, tossed back, shows where Scar has slept. Against one wall lie the huddled figures of tw squaws. Two other figures -- one being Debbie's -- sleep robes. Martin's eyes go to Scar's place and then rove slo and hold on:

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: She moves slightly so that the light strikes her fair hai Martin kneels close to her and gently touches her shoulde to awaken her. Her eyes open, then widen in fear. Martin  quickly claps a hand over his mouth. Silently she fights him, trying to pull the hand away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a hoarse whisper) Debbie... don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then her fingernails rake his hand. He winces and let go. She screams and tries to leap up. He grabs her. The o squaws wake -- begin squawking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) I'm takin' you whether you want to  or not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie sees something beyond him. Her eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a scream) MARTIN!

dialogues.speaker: SCAR
dialogues.text: He looms in the flap of the tepee much as he had over the grave when he first kidnapped her. He has a scalping knif in his hand. Scar whips his arm back. Behind him we see t other Comanche -- the one from the horse herd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin spins and his gun is out. He fans the trigger hamm twice -- and both slugs hit Scar. As the other Comanche l in, Martin's gun speaks again. And then he is on his feet catching Debbie by the arm -- unresisting now -- and pull her after him through the camp. Shouts and cries bespeak awakening of the camp.

dialogues.speaker: THE RANGER GROUP
dialogues.text: They are mounted and in line. The echo of a shot comes  bouncing back. Clayton is facing the men. He solemnly dof his hat and bows his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For these Thy gifts which we are  about to receive... (donning his hat, he  turns to the bugler) Sound that horn, son, and Leave Us  Go Amongst Them...YA-HEE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And shouting the rebel yell, he leads the charge. The yel is picked up by every man and the bugler sounds the charg as though he had a regiment at his back. Lt. Greenhill -- West Point beau sabreur in strange company -- has his sab at the "charge."

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CHARGE
dialogues.text: In the swamp of men and horses, we just have time to noti that Sam is darting a somewhat worried look at Greenhill' saber ominously close to his back. The charge is sounding the hooves are drumming and the men are yelling the way t did when they rode with Bedford Forrest -- reins in their teeth, guns in their fists.

dialogues.speaker: AS THE RANGERS HIT
dialogues.text: Comanches are running from the tepees, trying to reach th horse herd as the file of Rangers knifes in.  The bark of hand guns is a steady sound now -- and the Comanches have never been up against such marksmen. One charging Ranger  rides down a tepee. Another, with two guns drawn, scores running double on two Indians racing toward him from oppo sides of his fast-running horse. A dodging Comanche screa as a barrel-chested roan hits him broadside and sends him sprawling into the embers of the campfire.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: He yanks his horse back to its haunches, firing at a Coma crouched near the tepee. The charge races past him. Ethan swings off and runs to the tepee flap, whips it open and  glares. A squaw comes running out at him, knife upraised, but he knocks her sprawling with a full arm sweep. He tur and his face is a mask of frustration -- and then he free seeing what he has been looking for: EXT. THE INDIAN ENCAMPMENT - LONG SHOT - ETHAN'S P.O.V. Martin is running with Debbie, trying to pull her along,  while she kicks and claws and tries to break free. (They about thirty yards from the camp proper.) Riderless horse are milling, circling. O.s. we can hear the firing, the y

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan remounts and heads around the side of Scar's tepee. In the distance we see Martin and Debbie. The Rangers,  regrouping, are charging back through the camp, driving t Comanche horse herd.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN AND DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Martin hears Ethan's horse riding down at them; he turns, and Debbie pulls free and starts to run away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ethan! NO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes running into the path of Ethan's horse.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: as Martin runs and grabs hold of his stirrup, trying to f the horse to a stop. Ethan swings on him -- once, twice - and Martin is knocked sprawling. Ethan rides on, relentle

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE AND ETHAN
dialogues.text: She is running and dodging, trying to escape the horseman Ethan has his gun drawn. She ducks to one side and the ho goes past. Both figures are almost obscured in the dust.  Ethan spins his mount and charges after her. She runs and then falls -- and he is off his horse and striding toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan is at the left of CAMERA and slightly closer to the foreground, with Debbie at the right, supine on the groun and the dust swirling around her. Ethan draws and raises gun. The hammer goes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) I'm sorry, girl... Shut your eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dust clears. The CAMERA MOVES slightly forward along gun arm and HOLDS on Debbie's face -- the eyes gazing  fearlessly, innocently into Ethan's. We HOLD for a long m and then the gun lowers. Ethan slowly holsters it and wal over to her.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: He looks down at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) You sure favor your mother...

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO
dialogues.text: He extends his hand to her. She takes it and he helps her her feet. And then she is against his chest and his arm g protectingly about her. They are standing that way when M stumbles up -- and stares.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The line of Rangers is afoot now, each man near his horse each man with rifle out, pumping shot after shot at the  fleeting remnant of Comanches riding down the long valley with their scattered horse herd milling and criss-crossin in mid-ground... And then as the firing slackens, from af we can hear the blare of a cavalry bugle sounding the cha sign of the approach of Greenhill's troop.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING CLAYTON
dialogues.text: It is perhaps half an hour later. Clayton is very grim of face and occasionally wincing. His trousers are down over his ankles, his shirt-tails flapping over his long-handle red underwear. Behind him Charlie MacCorry is kneeling,  applying some crude first aid to Sam's rump. Beyond them  some of the Rangers are readying for the move-out. Sam lo up angrily as COLONEL GREENHILL, a guidon bearer, and bug ride in. Greenhill is a choleric man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton, if you were in my command  I'd have you courtmartialed for this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily, to MacCorry) Hurry it up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, sir... You wounded?   What is it, Sergeant -- a bullet or  an arrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie just gapes, but Clayton -- grim-lipped -- bends a meaningful glare on someone off. Greenhill looks that way

dialogues.speaker: LT. GREENHILL
dialogues.text: He is standing with his sabre at salute -- looking as  miserable as any shavetail would look when in disgrace. I could be that the end of the sabre has a pronounced bend.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: Sam suddenly slaps MacCorry's hand away and grabs for his pants and pulls them up -- and around a tepee come three  figures -- Ethan, Debbie, and Martin -- with Ethan holdin Debbie's hand. And Sam's face is split by a grin as he tu his shirt-tails in and goes to meet them.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: He is in a rocker on the porch. Suddenly he stares out an stops rocking. Faint in the distance, but coming closer, clop-clop of two horses, moving at a walk. A moment later Jorgensen emerges and comes to stand beside Mose, shading his eyes and squinting against the sun, still not recogni the distant horsemen.  He is joined by Mrs. Jorgensen. An then Laurie comes out and she too stares, frowning at fir then with dawning realization. Lars and Mrs. Jorgensen also begin to guess... to suspect and then to know. And Laurie starts to run.

dialogues.speaker: MOVING WITH LAURIE
dialogues.text: The CAMERA MOVES ahead of her as she runs blindly over th hard-packed ground, running as hard as she can toward the still unseen but nearing horsemen.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: Ethan has Debbie on the pommel of his saddle, his arm  supporting her, and she is asleep. Martin is riding besid them. Laurie comes running up to stare at Ethan and at th girl. He smiles and puts a finger to his lips -- cautioni her against waking Debbie -- and then he rides by. Laurie looks then at Martin. He doesn't know whether to smile or not; he just waits. And then she is beside him and she st onto his stirruped foot and vaults up beside him, and she kisses him just as she had on the day he left the graves take up the search. And still holding her beside him, he  rides slowly after Ethan and Debbie toward the house.
